[[File:Confindustria.svg|thumb]] The '''General Confederation of Italian Industry''' ({{lang-it|Confederazione generale dell'industria italiana}}), commonly known as '''Confindustria''', is the [[Italy|Italian]] [[employers' federation]] and national [[chamber of commerce]], founded in 1910. It groups together more than 113,000 voluntary member companies, accounting for nearly 4,200,000 individuals. It aims to help Italy's economic growth, assisting, in doing so, its members. It is a member of the [[International Organisation of Employers]] (IOE). The President is Vincenzo Boccia since 31 March 2016.
Confindustria was a founding member of several organizations, including ISTUD (Istituto Studi Direzionali) and Assingegneria (an organization set up by Confindustria, which has since merged with OICE, L'ingegneria italiana organizzata - which in itself belongs to Confindustria).
Members of Confindustria include ANIMA, Federation of the Italian Associations of Mechanical and Engineering Industries.
It owns the prominent newspaper ''[[Il Sole 24 Ore]]''. With local chapters all over Italy, it is popularly synonymous with Italian business.
==Branches==
These are the main branches of the Confindustria association: Federcostruzioni, Federprogetti, ACIMAC, ACIMGA, AFI, AGIS. AIE, AIMPES, AISCAT, ANAV, ANDIL, ANEPLA, ANFAO, ANFIA, ANFIDA, ANICA, ANIGAS, ANITEC, APT, ASSAEROPORTI, ASSICA, ASSISTAL, ASSITOL, ASSOBETON, ASSOBIODIESEL, ASSOBIRRA, ASSOCARNI, AICA, ASSONCONSULT, ASSOELETTRICA, ASSOGAS, ASSOIMMOBILIARE, ASSOLOGISTICA, ASSOMET, ASSONAVE. ASSOTTICA, ASSTEL, CONFINDUSTRIA ANCMA, Confindustria Ceramica, Confindustria Intellect, Confindustria Radio Televisioni, Farmindustria, Federpesca, Federunacoma, FEM, FISE, ITALGROB, MINERACQUA, TESSILIVARI, UCIMU, UNIC, UNIVIDEO, ACIMALL, ACIMIT, AGENS, AIDEPI, AIIPA, AIOP, AITEC, ANCIT, ANEF, ANES, ANDIA, ANIASA, ANICAV, ANITA, ANPAM, ASSAEREO, ASSALZOO, ASSINFORM, ASSITERNMINAL, ASSIV, ASSOBIBE, ASSOBIOMEDICA, ASSOCALZATURIFICI Italiani, ASSOCARTA, ASSOCOMAPLAST, ASSOCONTROL, ASSOFOND, ASSOGRAFICI, ASSOLATTE, ASSOMAC, ASSOMINERARIA, ASSOSISTEMA, ASSOVETRO, CAGEMA, Confindustria CECED Italia, Confindustria Federorafi, Confindustria marmomacchine, Conditarma, [[Federacciai]], Federterme, Federvini, [[FIMI]], IGAS, ITALMOPA, OICE, UCIMA, UCINA, Unione Petrolifera.
==Former Presidents== * Luigi Benetton (1910 – 1913) * Ferdinando Bocca (1913 – 1918) * Dante Ferraris (1918 – 1919) * Giovanni Battista Pirelli (1919) * Giovanni Silvestri (1919 – 1920) * Ettore Conti (1920 – 1921) * Raimondo Targetti (1922 – 1923) * Antonio Stefano Benni (1923 – 1934) * Alberto Pirelli (1934) * Giuseppe Volpi di Misurata (1934 – 1943) * Giovanni Balella (1943) * Giuseppe Mazzini (1943) * Fabio Friggeri (1944 – 1945) * Angelo Costa (1945 – 1955) * Alighiero De Micheli (1955 – 1961) * Furio Cicogna (1961 – 1966) * Angelo Costa (1966 – 1970) * Renato Lombardi (1970 – 1974) * Giovanni Agnelli (1974 – 1976) * Guido Carli (1976 – 1980) * Vittorio Merloni (1980 – 1984) * Luigi Lucchini (1984 – 1988) * [[Sergio Pininfarina]] (1988 – 1992) * Luigi Abete (1992 – 1996) * Giorgio Fossa (1996 – 2000) * Antonio D'Amato (May 25, <!--voted for office the day before; took over on the 25th--> 2000 – 2004) * [[Luca Cordero di Montezemolo]] (May 27, 2004 – May 20, 2008)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/people/displayStory.cfm?story_id=2685931 |title=Face value: Putting Italy back on the podium |publisher=The Economist |date= May 22, 2004|accessdate=2012-12-18}}</ref> * [[Emma Marcegaglia]] (May 21, 2008 – March 21, 2012)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/eiro/2008/04/articles/it0804029i.htm |title=Confindustria elects first-ever female president |publisher=Eurofound.europa.eu |date= |accessdate=2012-12-18}}</ref> * Giorgio Squinzi (2012-2016) * Vincenzo Boccia (2016-)
==See also== * [[Economy of Italy]] * [[List of national employers' federations]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.confindustria.it/ }} {{it icon}} * [http://www.confindustria.it/DBImg2002.nsf/HTMLPages/ChiSiamoEng Official site - English overview] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20040731031737/http://www.psa.ac.uk/cps/1996/lanz.pdf Confindustria and the Party System in Italy] (PDF)
{{Confederation of European Business}}

revision.text:
'''Horace Lucian Arnold''' (June 25, 1837 - January 25, 1915[http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=chi.098722507;view=1up;seq=913 Editorial comment] in: ''Industrial management; the engineering magazine.'' c.1 v.48 1914/15. p. 889) was an American [[engineer]], inventor, engineering journalist and early American writer on [[management]], who wrote about [[shop management]], [[cost accounting]], and other specific management techniques.[[Yates, JoAnne]]. "Evolving information use in firms, 1850-1920: ideology and information techniques and technologies." (1992). He also wrote under the names '''Hugh Dolnar''', '''John Randol''',[[Jenks, Leland H.]] "Early phases of the management movement." Administrative Science Quarterly (1960): 421-447. and '''Henry Roland'''. With [[Henry R. Towne]], [[Captain Henry Metcalfe|Henry Metcalfe]], [[Emile Garcke]], [[John Tregoning]] and [[Slater Lewis]] he is known as early systematizer of management of the late 19th century.[[JoAnne Yates]] (1993) ''Control Through Communication: The Rise of System in American Management.'' p 12 == Biography == Born in New York, Arnold grew up in [[Lafayette, Walworth County, Wisconsin]]. Here Arnold started his career working in [[machine shop]]s. For twelve years he was journeyman machinist in western river and lake engine shops. Subsequently he was superintendent at the Ottawa Machine Shop and Foundry; department foreman at the [[E. W. Bliss Company]]; superintendent at the Stiles & Parker Press Company of [[Norman C. Stiles]]; and designer for the [[Pratt & Whitney Measurement Systems|Pratt and Whitney Company]] in Hartford, Connecticut.''[http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015048905544;view=1up;seq=1278 Engineering Magazine],'' Vol. 11 (1896), p. 1228[[Joseph August Litterer]] (1986). ''The emergence of systematic management as shown by the literature of management from 1870-1900.'' p. 250 In those days Arnold had also started inventing new tools. In 1858 he had patented his first invention, a [[marble]] [[saw]].[http://www.google.com/patents/US20981 Patents US20981] for a stone-sawing machine, patented July 27, 1858.Robert Messenger. "[http://oztypewriter.blogspot.nl/2011/09/on-this-day-in-typewriter-history-cxiii.html On This Day in Typewriter History (CXIII); september 10]," at oztypewriter.blogspot.nl, 13 Sept. 2011 [[File:Type Writing Machine by H.L Arnold, 1896 (1).jpg|thumb|Type Writing Machine by Arnold, 1896]] In the next ten years Arnold moved to worked at places from Ottawa, Illinois; Grand Rapids, Michigan; Middletown, Connecticut; eventually to Brooklyn, New York, where he would stay. He continued to research and invented a range of products from "metal cutters to recorders, book binding, book stitching and book covering machines, mixers, letter locks..., piston water meters and water motors, knitting machines, 'explosive' and internal combustion engines and combustion generators, and clutches." Late 1880s Arnold started his own [[typewriter]] company. In the 1890s he started as a technical journalist for journals such as the ''[[Engineering Magazine]]'', the ''Automobile Trade Journal,'' and the ''[[American Machinist]].''. He wrote his articles using different pen names of which Henry Roland and Hugh Dolnar were the best known.[[Hounshell, David A.]] (1984), ''From the American System to Mass Production, 1800-1932: The Development of Manufacturing Technology in the United States''. p. 91[[Yehouda Shenhav|Yehouda A. Shenhav]] (2002). ''Manufacturing Rationality: The Engineering Foundations of the Managerial Revolution''. Oxford University Press. p. 221 Arnold also wrote at least three books published by the Engineering Magazine Press in New York. Arnold died of pneumonia in [[Detroit]] on January 25, 1915 at the age of 77.''Automobile Topics'' Vol. 36 (1914-15). p. 1106 An article in ''Business Week'' (1966) recalled, that "every reader of the ''Engineering Magazine'' knew what the connection was: Arnold had died on the job of tracking down the full Ford story."''Business Week''. Part 3. (1966). p. 127 == Work == === ''Engineering Magazine'', 1895-1914 === In the 1890s Arnold started writing on technology and management subjects in ''[[Engineering Magazine]]'', and would continue to contribute until his death. In 1898 H.M. Norris reviewedH.M. Norris "A simple and effective system of shop cost-keeping". ''Engineering Magazine'' Vol 16. (1898). p. 383
''Mr. Henry Roland's [Horace L. Arnold's] many valuable contributions on this subject to ''The Engineering Magazine'' afford a rare opportunity for the study of the practice followed by many leading firms, and contain much of interest to every one connected with shop management. His incisive drawing of the difficulties to be met and overcome in the re-organization of an old and well-established business will strike home to the hearts of many managers. If proprietors could be brought to a better understanding of what a strong organization would mean to them, the work of the manager would be much simplified.''
For this work Arnold is nowadays considered among the foremost writers on management techniques, such as wage systems, [[production control]] and inventory control. He was among the foremost writers of the late 19th century, such as [[Henry R. Towne]], [[Captain Henry Metcalfe|Henry Metcalfe]], [[John Tregoning]] and [[Slater Lewis]]; and among early 20th-century authors as [[Frederick Winslow Taylor]], [[Charles Edward Knoeppel|C.E. Knoeppel]], [[Harrington Emerson]], [[Clinton Edgar Woods]], [[Charles U. Carpenter]], [[Alexander Hamilton Church]] and [[Henry Gantt]]. === ''Modern Machine-Shop Economics,'' 1896 === In 1896 Arnold wrote a first series of articles for the ''[[Engineering Magazine]]'' about [[machine shop]]s, entitled "Modern Machine-Shop Economics." This work stretched out from production technology, production methods and factory lay-out to time studies, production planning, and machine shop management. Some of the companies still exist. {{Gallery |title= ''Modern Machine-Shop Economics,'' 1896 |width=200 | height=200 | lines=3 |align=center |File:Browns & Sharpe Shops, Providence RI, 1896.jpg |alt1=Browns & Sharpe Shops, Providence RI, 1896 |[[Brown & Sharpe|Browns & Sharpe Shops]], Providence RI, 1896 |File:Colt's Armory, 1896.jpg |alt2=Colt Armory, 1896 |[[Colt Armory]], 1896 |File:General Electric Shops, Schenectady, NY, aerial view, 1896.jpg |alt3=General Electric Shops, Schenectady, NY, aerial view, 1896 |[[General Electric]] Shops, Schenectady, NY, aerial view, 1896 |File:The Pratt & Whitney Shops, Hartford, Conn, 1896.jpg |alt4=Pratt & Whitney Shops, Hartford, Conn, 1896 |[[Pratt & Whitney Measurement Systems#history|Pratt & Whitney]] Shops, Hartford, Conn, 1896 }} In the next years a few more series of articles on these topic would follow in the ''[[Engineering Magazine]]'' . === ''Six examples of successful shop management,'' 1897 === In 1897 Arnold published a second series, entitled "Six examples of successful shop management." [[Francis G. Burton|Burton]] (1899) summarized, that these papers "giving six examples of successful shop management, wherein the influence of fair and just dealing, of isolation and environment, and of careful detailed supervision and definite contracts, upon the prosperity of the factories and the contentment of the work people are cleverly traced. The success is, however, in most cases, that of isolated works under the dominance of exceptionally skilful managers, who impress their own rectitude and personality on the establishment, rather than of any system which recommends itself for general adoption."* [[Francis G. Burton]]. ''[https://archive.org/stream/commercialmanag00burtgoog#page/n189/mode/2up The Commercial Management of Engineering Works].'' (1899). p. 147. The first article recounted about the Whitin Machine Shop in Whitinsville in [[Northbridge, Massachusetts]] (see images), at its peak the largest manufacturer of textile machines in the world.{{cite book|last= Navin|first = Thomas R|authorlink= |title =The Whitin Machine Works since 1831: A textile machinery company in an industrial village; Harvard studies in business history| publisher=Russel and Russel|year=1969}} And the second article was about the [[Yale (company)|Yale & Towne Manufacturing Co]] (see images), where [[Henry R. Towne]] was president at that time.Arnold (1897, p. 395) In those days the company faced serious labour problems, and Towne introduced a series of "measures. He ended the contract system, introduced piece rates, which he guaranteed for one year, and established systematic procedures for dealing with grievances. On new work Towne set minimum and maximum earnings levels so that piece rates, if incorrect, would not unduly punish or reward workers.Arnold (1897, p. 404-6)..."Daniel Nelson (1996). ''Managers and Workers: Origins of the Twentieth-Century Factory System in the United States, 1880–1920.'' 1996, p. 53 {{Gallery |title= Six examples of successful shop management, 1897 |width=200 | height=200 | lines=3 |align=center |File:Whithin Machine Shop, 1897.jpg |alt1=Whitin Machine Shop, 1897 |[[Whitin Machine Works|Whitin Machine Shop]], 1897 |File:Whitin Thomson-Houston Electric Locomotive, 1897.jpg |alt2=Whitin Thomson-Houston Electric Locomotive, 1897 |[[Electric locomotive]] at Whitin [[Thomson-Houston Electric Company|Thomson-Houston]], 1897 |File:Yale & Towne Manufacturing Co, 1897.jpg |alt3=Yale & Towne Manufacturing Co, 1897 |[[Yale (company)|Yale & Towne Manufacturing Co]], 1897 |File:Yale & Towne Manufactoring Co, The Tool Room, 1897.jpg |alt4=Tool Room of Yale & Towne Manufactoring Co, 1897 |Tool room at the [[Yale (company)|Yale & Towne Manufactoring Co]], 1897 }} In the fourth article, entitled "Pre-Eminent Success of the Differential Piece Rate System", Arnold described the [[Taylor System]] as worked out by the [[Midvale Steel Company]].C. Bertrand Thompson. "The Literature of Scientific Management," ''The Quarterly Journal of Economics,'' Vol. 28, No. 3 (May, 1914), pp. 506-557. Published by: Oxford University Press Article [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1884986 Stable URL]. Especially the operation of the [[piece-rate system]] at Midvale Steel was described, and the analytic method of rate-fixing deveped by [[Frederick Winslow Taylor]].Arnold (1897, p. 834) In those days the rates in the piecework system were set by the supervisor.Arnold (1897, p. 96-98)Daniel Nelson (1996, 45-46.). Burton commented, that this paper contained contains some pregnant remarks on the increase of output through the stimulus of unfettered piecework rates, and is deserving of the most grave consideration by English managers and workmen... The justice and economy of piece-work, even under fixed and absolute rates, is admirably expressed." As Arnold stated:
Not only does the fast man do more work, but that work is done at a reduced fixed-charges cost, and the intelligent manager discovers that he must greatly increase the pay of the speedy man or decrease the pay of the slow man to make each equally profitable. Under these conditions the piece-rate at once suggests itself as a remedy. The piece-rate stimulates the slow artisan, and justly rewards the quick worker, tends to increase the area output, and lessen the fixed-charges drawback on profits.Arnold (1897, p. 831)
On the whole series Kaufman (2008) commented, that "a distinctive feature of the six examples of successful shop management highlighted by [Arnold] is that they practiced a relatively benevolent and light-handed form of [[autocracy]] in which the golden rule of fair dealing and 'doing unto others' was a guiding management principle. This form of enlightened autocracy was frequently labeled '[[industrial paternalism]]' with the idea that the company was a family, the employer played the role of the benevolent but exacting father (the paternal figure), and the employees were akin to teenage children who, with suitable guidance and discipline, would work together to produce what the family required (as on a family farm)."Bruce E. Kaufman. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=dAr3GmiKG5MC&pg=PA11 Managing the Human Factor: The Early Years of Human Resource Management in American Industry].'' 2008. p. 11 === ''Effective systems of finding and keeping shop costs'', 1898 === In 1897-98 Arnold published a first series about cost keeping in [[machine shop]]s, entitled "Cost-Keeping Methods in Machine-Shop and Foundry," and in 1898 he published a second series of six articles, entitled "Effective systems of finding and keeping shop costs." This work contributed to the wider discussion among British and American engineers about the development of a costing system for factories. Initial contributions were made by [[Captain Henry Metcalfe|Metcalfe]] (1885/86), [[Emile Garcke|Garcke]] (1887), [[Henry R. Towne|Towne]] (1889), [[F.A. Halsey|Halsey]] (1891),etc., and further contributions came from [[Sterling Bunnell|Bunnell]], [[Alexander Hamilton Church|Church]], [[Hugo Diemer|Diemer]], [[Henry Laurence Gantt|Gantt]], [[Lingan S. Randolph|Randolph]], [[Oberlin Smith]], [[Frederick Winslow Taylor|Taylor]], among others.Murray C. Wells (1996) "[http://clio.lib.olemiss.edu/cdm/ref/collection/aah/id/353 Engineering and accounting]" in: ''History of Accounting: An International Encyclopedia.'' [[Michael Chatfield]], [[Richard Vangermeersch]] eds. 1996/2014. p. 269-70. These discussion focussed on topics such as "costing methods, estimating, overhead allocations, economies of scale and other topics normally associated with the [[accounting]]." Wells (1996) stated, that these early pioneers in the field of [[cost accounting]], became aware of the "arbitrary nature of cost allocations... [proceeding] accountants by 50 years or more." In that respect, Arnold considered these costs 'probable', yet considered the information from the system 'absolute correct.' Randolph and Diemer (1903) would speak of 'accurate costs' and 'correct' or 'accurate' information. Wells added that these "engineers (as did the accountants who followed them) failed to recognize the difference between a system that allocated all of the overhead costs "accurately"—there were no residual costs unallocated—and the arbitrary cost of production that resulted from the use of some broad allocation base such as direct wages." === Written records in business === Arnold was known as promoter of written records in business. Arnold (1901) was convinced, that "Even if entire honesty and sincerity prevailed at all times in all business transactions, the mere differences due to variations in individual understandings of orders would render it impossible to conduct any business of magnitude on verbal specifications."As cited in [[Joseph August Litterer]] ''The emergence of systematic management as shown by the literature of management from 1870-1900''. Garland, 1 aug. 1986. p. 109 === ''Ford Methods and the Ford Shops'', 1915 === [[File:Ford methods and the Ford shops, 1915.jpg|thumb|480px|''Ford Methods and the Ford Shops'', title plate and title page, 1915]] Under the penname Hugh Dolnar, Arnold also wrote for the leading automotive magazine ''Automobile Trade Journal'', where he was one of the most respected reporters.Francois Therou (1971) ''Buick: "the golden era", 1903-1915''. p. 5. [[Henry Ford]] admired his work[[James M. Rubenstein]] (2001) ''Making and Selling Cars: Innovation and Change in the U.S.''. p. 358. and early 1910s invited him to study his factory and write about the new production techniques at the [[Highland Park Ford Plant]]. This resulted in the book ''Ford Methods and the Ford Shops'', which he left unfinished after his death in 1915. The engineer Fay Leone Faurote (1881-1938) finished his work, which was published in 1915 by the Engineering Magazine company, and became Arnold's best known work. This book introduced the moving assembly line to the larger audience,[[Alfred Dupont Chandler]] (1977) ''The Visible Hand: The Managerial Revolution in American Business.'' p. 561. Chandler added that "the story of the introduction of the moving assembly line is dramatically told in [[Allan Nevins]] and Frank E. Hill, ''Ford: The Times, The Men and The Company'' (New York, 1954), chap. 18." explained about its slow progress,W. Licht (2001) ''The Rise and Fall of Mass Production'' and suggested that this system could be applied in any small machine factory.Hounsell (1984: p. 375) == Reception == A short obituary in the ''Cycle and Automobile Trade Journal'' (1915) wrote: :''Those readers who have been with us for five or more years are familiar with "Hugh Dolnar" which was the pen name adopted by Horace L. Arnold. For years "Hugh Dolnar" wrote car descriptions and special automobile engineering articles for the Automobile Trade Journal. His work was by far the most thorough and valuable published during the formative period of the greater automobile industry, and had a style and snap to it which has never been equaled by any other technical writer on automobile construction."[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=nyp.33433090781869;view=1up;seq=836 Horace L. Arnold (Hugh Dolnar), died]," in: ''Cycle and Automobile Trade Journal,'' Volume 19. Chilton Company, 1915. p. 83. His last work for the ''Automobile Trade Journal'' had been on the Ford Factory, the 50-page longe article "The Ford Achievement",.Hugh Dolnar (1913; 115-165) published in April, 1914. == Publications == Arnold wrote some books, and many articles on [[shop management]], [[cost accounting]], and other specific management techniques. His books: * Arnold, Horace L. ''[https://archive.org/details/completecostkeep00arnouoft The Complete cost-keeper; some original systems of shop cost-keeping or factory accounting, together with an exposition of the advantages of account keeping by means of cards instead of books, and a description of various mechanical aids to factory accounting]''. The Engineering Magazine Press. 1900/1903 * Arnold, Horace L. 1903. ''[https://archive.org/details/factorymanagerac00arnorich The Factory manager and accountant, some examples of the latest American factory practice; collected and arranged by Horace Lucian Arnold (Henry Roland)].'' The Engineering Magazine company. 1903; 2nd ed. 1905; 3rd ed. 1910. * Arnold, Horace L. ''[https://openlibrary.org/books/OL13554528M/Ford_methods_and_the_Ford_shops Ford Methods and the Ford Shops].'' With Fay Leone Faurote and preface by [[Charles Buxton Going]]. The Engineering Magazine company, 1915. ;Articles, a selection: * Arnold, Horace L. "Production Up to the Power Limit." ''Engineering Magazine'' 9 (1895): 916-24. * Arnold, Horace L. "Modern Machine-Shop Economics." in ''Engineering Magazine'' 11. 1896 Parts of "Modern Machine-Shop Economics," 1896: * [https://archive.org/stream/factoryindustria11newy#page/58/mode/2up I — The Location of the Shop]. p. 59-66 * [https://archive.org/stream/factoryindustria11newy#page/262/mode/2up II — Prime Requisites of Shop Construction.]. p. 263-298 * [https://archive.org/stream/factoryindustria11newy#page/468/mode/2up III — A Modern Plan for a Modern Shop]. p. 469-477. * [https://archive.org/stream/factoryindustria11newy#page/472/mode/2up IV — The important problem of tool:Equipement]. p. 473-95. * "[https://archive.org/stream/factoryindustria11newy#page/882/mode/2up V. "[https://archive.org/stream/factoryindustria20newy#page/364/mode/2up The expense account of the machine shop]," ''The Engineering Magazine''. 20 (1900). p. 365-72 * Hugh Dolnar, "The Ford 4-Cylinder Runabout," ''Cycle and Automobile Trade Journal'' 11 (August 1, 1906): 108 * Hugh Dolnar, ''Automobile Trade Journal'', article: ''The Lambert, 1906 Line of Automobiles'', Chilton Company, v.10 January 1906 * H.L. Arnold, "[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015011400986;view=2up;seq=690 Ford Methods And The Ford Shops VI]" in ''Engineering Magazine,'' 47, August 1914, p. 667-692. * H.L. Arnold, "[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015011400986;view=2up;seq=880 Ford Methods And The Ford Shops VII]" in ''Engineering Magazine,'' 47, September 1914, p. 856-886. * Hugh Dolnar, "[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=nyp.33433090782214;view=2up;seq=130 The Ford Achievement]," ''Automobile Trade Journal,'' v. 18 (Apr.-June 1914). p. 115-165 == Patents == About 25 of Arnold's inventions got patented. A selection: * 1861, [http://www.google.com/patents/US33229 Patent US 33229], for an improvement in machines for dressing hides. * 1887, [http://www.google.com/patents/US410629 Patent US 410629] for a type writer machine. * 1891, [http://www.google.com/patents/US449595 Patent US 449595] for a book binder machine. * 1896, [http://www.google.com/patents/US572350 Patent US 572350] for a type writing machine. * 1899, [http://www.google.com/patents/US637495 US 637495] for a milling-cutter tooth. * 1900, [http://www.google.com/patents/US661479 Patent US 661479] for a clutch. * 1901, [http://www.google.com/patents/US666840 Patent US 666840] for a fluid-actuated motor. * 1912, [http://www.google.com/patents/US1024817 Patents US 1024817] for a crane shaft. == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == {{commons category}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arnold, Horace Lucian}} [[Category:1837 births]] [[Category:1915 deaths]] [[Category:Engineers from New York (state)]] [[Category:American business and financial journalists]] [[Category:American male journalists]] [[Category:American business theorists]] [[Category:American technology journalists]] [[Category:Writers from Rochester, New York]] [[Category:People from Walworth County, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Journalists from New York (state)]]

'''IWA & OutdoorClassics''' is an annual [[trade fair]] held in the [[Messezentrum Nuremberg]] ([[Nuremberg]] Exhibition Centre) in [[Bavaria]], [[Germany]] for the [[hunting]], [[shooting sports]], [[outdoor recreation|outdoor activity]] products and [[private security|civilian security]]/[[law enforcement]] equipment industries. "IWA" is an abbreviation for ''Internationale Waffen Ausstellung'' (International Weapons Exhibition).
IWA & OutdoorClassics has been one of the world's leading exhibitions for the [[firearm]], [[airgun]] and weapon accessory sector for 40 years. Approximately 1561 exhibitors with an international share of 80% presented their products and services in 2018 to more than 46,500 trade visitors from 121 countries. The international share of visitors is about 62%, which makes IWA & OutdoorClassics an important multinational occasion for the industry.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.expobeds.com/event/iwa-outdoorclassics|title=IWA & OutdoorClassics - Info - And - Stats|date=|df=}}</ref>
== See also == *[[SHOT Show]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.iwa.info/en/ IWA & OutdoorClassics homepage] *[https://www.fair-point.com/event/iwa-outdoorclassics/ IWA & OutdoorClassics statistics 2014-2015]
{{DEFAULTSORT:IWA and OutdoorClassics}} [[Category:Trade fairs in Germany]]

{{Infobox person | name = Jaime Gilinski Bacal | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|12|14|df=yes}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = London, England | nationality = Colombian | education = | alma_mater = [[Georgia Tech]]
[[Harvard Business School]] | occupation = Banker | known for = | home_town = | salary = | networth = US$3.7 billion (May 2018){{cite web|title=Forbes profile: Jaime Gilinski Bacal|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/jaime-gilinski-bacal/|website=Forbes|accessdate=15 May 2018}} | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | boards = | spouse = Raquel Gilinski | children = 4 | parents = [[Isaac Gilinski Sragowicz]]
Perla Gilinski | relatives = | website = }} '''Jaime Gilinski Bacal''' (born 14 December 1957) is a Colombian banker and [[real estate developer]]. Gilinski resides in London. According to ''[[Forbes]]'', he is the second richest person in Colombia, with a net worth of US$3.9 billion as of May 2018. == Early life == He is the son of [[Isaac Gilinski Sragowicz]], a banker and himself the son of Lithuanian Jewish immigrants. Gilinski earned his BS in [[Industrial Engineering]] from [[Georgia Tech]] in 1978, and an MBA from [[Harvard Business School]] in 1980. == Banking == In the 1990s, Gilinski acquired the Colombian assets of BCCI (Bank of Credit and Commerce International) for a nominal sum after its global collapse. Renamed Banco Andino, it became one of the most efficient banks in the Colombian banking system within four years. The Gilinski Group sold the reconstituted bank for a reported $70 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.semana.com/noticias-nacion/regreso-gilinski/81674.aspx|title=El regreso de los Gilinski|accessdate=2009-07-13|publisher=Semana.com}} The family then moved to purchase Banco de Colombia for $365 million, in what was then the largest privatization in Colombia's history. A group of premier private equity investors led by Morgan Stanley Asset Management investing $65 million, billionaire [[George Soros]] investing $50 million and Tiger Asset Management with $35 million together with more than 100 other European and North American institutional investors co-invested with Gilinski. Later, the family sold control of the bank to Banco Industrial Colombiano, and its controlling stakeholder Sindicato Antioqueño, in a deal valued at $800 million, among Colombia's largest deals.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/26/business/big-bank-in-colombia-is-purchasing-a-rival.html|title=Big Bank in Colombia Is Purchasing a Rival| accessdate=2009-06-05|publisher=New York Times | date=1997-08-26}} Gilinski received $418 million for its stake and retained a minority position in the new bank as part of the deal. As of 2018, Bancolombia was the largest in Colombia with a market capitalization of $11 billion on the [[NYSE]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bankcali.com/?p=21|title=Banking in Colombia|accessdate=2009-07-13}} In 2003, Gilinski acquired and subsequently merged Banco Sudameris and Banco Tequendema. This merger created GNB Sudameris, a bank with assets of over US $10 billion that ranks among the largest private Colombian banks as of 2018. The purchase of Servibanca, an ATM network with over 2,600 machines, and Suma Valores, a stock exchange commission agent company, has further expanded the network. In May 2012, HSBC announced the sale of its Latin American operations (Colombia, Peru, Paraguay) to Banco GNB Sudameris for $400 million in cash. {{citation needed|date=May 2018}} In September 2013, Banco Sabadell announced that Gilinski became its largest shareholder as the anchor investor in a US $1.8 billion capital raise. Through the ABB and share rights issue, Gilinski's investment totals approximately $500 million. Banco Sabadell is the 5th largest bank in Spain, with over US $220 billion in assets and a 13% market share.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} The Gilinski group also owns Yupi, a snack food company in Latin America, and exports to nine countries. Gilinski Group also owns Rimax Plastics, which was founded by his father Isaac Gilinski.{{cite web|url=http://www.semana.com/noticias-portada/sueno-crecer/111307.aspx|title=El Sueno de crecer|accessdate=2009-06-24|publisher=Semana.com}} == Real estate == In partnership with [[London & Regional Properties]], Gilinski is developing the [[Panama Pacifico]]{{cite web|url=http://www.panama-pacifico.com/SecondaryTemplate.aspx?task=view&option=content&id=300|title=Construction commences in Howard|accessdate=2009-06-02|publisher=Canal 13 - Telemetro.com}} business and residential development in [[Panama City]], Panama. Jaime Gilinski and his partners [[Ian and Richard Livingstone]] beat 16 other international firms in a competition to develop the project. The $10 billion project, based on the former Howard Air Force Base in Panama, includes {{convert|2750|acre|km2}} of land, which makes it one of the largest development projects in the world.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} == Philanthropy == In the 1990s, the Gilinskis contributed US$8 million to the Fundacion Santa Fe. This was during Jaime Gilinski's time as chairman of Banco de Colombia.{{cite web|url=http://www.fsfb.org.co/node/226|title=Benefactores|accessdate=2009-07-28|publisher=Fundacion Santa Fe de Bogota|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140226142710/http://www.fsfb.org.co/node/226|archivedate=2014-02-26|df=}} La Fundación Santa Fe de Bogotá supports Santa Fe Hospital in Bogotá. Founded in 1972, this hospital is recognized as Colombia’s most technologically advanced.{{cite web|url=http://www.fsfb.org.co/fsfb?q=node/294|title=Conozca la Historia de la Fundación Santa Fe de Bogotá|accessdate=2013-03-09|publisher=Fundacion Santa Fe de Bogota|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140226134624/http://www.fsfb.org.co/fsfb?q=node%2F294|archivedate=2014-02-26|df=}} Gilinski is the chair of Capital Projects for The Chabad House at Harvard University.{{cite web|url = http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2003/4/7/harvard-chabad-dedicates-new-home-harvard/|title = Harvard Chabad Dedicates New Home|accessdate = 2016-02-08|publisher = The Harvard Crimson}} The Chabad House at Harvard is a Jewish [[student organization]] that provides educational, social, and recreational programming for students and faculty.{{cite web|url = http://chabadharvard.org/about/vision-and-impact|title = Vision & Values|accessdate = 2016-02-08|publisher = The Chabad House at Harvard}} Through the Jaime and Raquel Gilinski Endowment, Gilinski supports the [[David Rockefeller Center for Latin American Studies]] at [[Harvard University]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~icop/otherlatinosprogram.html|title=Other Latinos Program|accessdate=2009-06-02|publisher=Harvard University}} ==Personal life== He is married to Raquel Gilinski. They have four children and live in London, England. He has further houses in New York, Panama, Miami and Colombia. Jaime and Raquel Gilinski have also established the Jaime and Raquel Gilinski Fellowship at [[Harvard Business School]], awarded to MBA students from Colombia and Panama, with a secondary preference for students from other Latin American countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.alumni.hbs.edu/giving/fellowship_list.html|title=Recent Fellowships List|accessdate=2010-06-11|publisher=Harvard Business School}} == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.jgbbank.com/ JGB Bank Website] * [http://www.panama-pacifico.com/ Panama Pacifico Website] * {{YouTube|7miFGwOxtQM|Jaime Gilinski speaking at Chabad House}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gilinski Bacal, Jaime}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Cali]] [[Category:Colombian people of Lithuanian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Colombian Jews]] [[Category:Colombian expatriates in England]] [[Category:Georgia Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Colombian bankers]] [[Category:Colombian businesspeople]] [[Category:Colombian industrial engineers]] [[Category:Colombian philanthropists]] [[Category:Colombian billionaires]]

'''Jon Ramon Melendez Aboitiz''' (April 26, 1948 – November 30, 2018)<ref>"Philippines, Manila, Civil Registration, 1899-1984," database with images, ''FamilySearch''(https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:QKJP-91PR : 26 May 2016), Jon Ramon Aboitiz, 26 Apr 1948; citing Birth, Manila, Metropolitan Manila, Philippines, Civil Registry Office, City Hall of Manila; FHL microfilm 1,504,340.</ref> was a [[Spanish Filipino]] businessman, and the president of the Aboitiz & Company and [[Aboitiz Equity Ventures]], part of the Aboitiz Group.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://www.aboitiz.com/AFI/index.php?p=33|work=Aboitiz Group|accessdate=6 March 2011}}</ref> == Biographie == He started with the Aboitiz Group in 1970, after graduating from the [[University of Santa Clara]], [[California]] with a B.S. Commerce, major in Management. From a manager he became its president in 1976 and in 1991 became president of Aboitiz & Co. of the Aboitiz Shipping Corp.
He held various positions in the Aboitiz Group, including chairman and chief executive officer (CEO) of [[Davao Light & Power Co., Inc.]], chairman of Veco and Aboitiz Jebsen Bulk Transport Corp., and director of Hapag-Lloyd Phils., Cotabato Ice Plant Inc. and Bukidnon Hydropower Corp.
Aboitiz also served as trustee of the Ramon Aboitiz Foundation Inc., the Aboitiz Group Foundation Inc. and the Association of Philippine Foundations, and was a member of the Board of Advisors, Washington Sycip Policy Forum at the [[Asian Institute of Management]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *http://www.forbes.com/lists/2009/86/philippines-billionaires-09_Jon-Ramon-Aboitiz_IOLY.html *http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=30466794&ticker=AEV:PM&previousCapId=30854892&previousTitle=ABOITIZ%20POWER%20COR *http://www.people.nfo.ph/businessman/jon-ramon-aboitiz/ *http://www.sunstar.com.ph/superbalita-cebu/balita/presidente-nia-sa-sugbo * [http://www.aboitiz.com/ Aboitiz Group]

[[File:Joost-mller-1348345045.jpg|thumb|Joost Möller]]
''' J.H. (Joost) Möller''' (born May 20, 1967 in [[Eindhoven]]) is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] politician of the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] (VVD).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.blikopnieuws.nl/bericht/116223/Sieneke_en_Joost_M%F6ller_tokkelen_van_reuzenrad.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120724051214/http://www.blikopnieuws.nl/bericht/116223/Sieneke_en_Joost_M%F6ller_tokkelen_van_reuzenrad.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=July 24, 2012|title=Sieneke en Joost Möller tokkelen van reuzenrad|date=July 16, 2010|work=Blik op Nieuws|language=Dutch|accessdate=September 27, 2011}}</ref>
Möller was a [[councillor (NL)|councillor]] of [[Tilburg]] from 1999 to 2008. Since 2008 he has been an [[wethouder|alderman]] of this [[North Brabant]] municipality. From 2002 to 2010, he was also owner of an [[employment agency]] called ''Talentflex''.
Möller studied [[business economics]] at [[Tilburg University]].
== References == * {{nl}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20130520004857/http://www.tilburg.nl/gemeente/ep/channelView.do?channelId=-12986&displayPage=%2Fep%2Fchannel%2Ftl_channel_default_program.jsp&pageTypeId=9960 Tilburg municipality] {{Reflist}}

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{unreferenced|date=April 2013}} {{MedalTableTop|medals= {{Medal|Sport|Men's [[Olympic weightlifting|Weightlifting]]}} {{Medal|Country|{{flag|Malaya}}}} {{Medal|Comp|[[British Empire Games]]}} {{Medal|Gold | [[1950 British Empire Games|1950 Auckland]] | 310.5 kg}} }} '''Koh Eng Tong''' (1921-2006) was a [[Malaysian people|Malaysian]] athlete, professional [http://www.photographermalaysia.my/ photographer] and founder of Eng Tong System Sdn. Bhd, a supplier of professional photographic equipment and other products in [[Malaysia]]. He won the first [[Commonwealth Games]] gold medal for [[Federation of Malaya|Malaya]] and was instrumental in bringing Malaysian sports to world prominence. == British Empire and the Commonwealth Games == In 1950, Koh Eng Tong won Malaya's first Gold Medal at the [[1950 British Empire Games]] in Weightlifting (featherweight) held in [[Auckland]], New Zealand. At these games he lifted 310.5 kg (684.5 lbs) to win the featherweight Gold. Although at the time, Malaya was not yet an independent country, the British Government in Malaya allowed an organised a team of four weightlifters from Malaya to participate for the first time in the Games under the Union Jack. The 1950 games was also the first occasion weightlifting was introduced. Due to the absence of a sports organisation, the weightlifters had to pay their own expenses to participate at the games. All four lifters medaled, bringing back 2 gold, 1 silver, and 1 bronze. In 1951, he was rated one of the top ten Featherweight Lifters in the World{{by whom|date=April 2013}}. In 1954, due to lack of financial support, Malaya could not participate in the [[1954 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] held in Vancouver, and Koh was not given an opportunity to defend his title, which might have resulted in a repeat victory. The 1954 winning weight in the featherweight category was 690 lbs, 5 lbs more than the total achieved by Koh Eng Tong in 1950. == Olympic games == Malaya was officially recognised by the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) in 1954. Mr. Koh was among a contingent of 33 athletes sent by the [[Federation of Malaya Olympic Council]] to participate in the [[1956 Summer Olympics]] in Melbourne. Although 6 years removed from his gold medal performance at the British Empire games. Mr. Koh represented Malaya in the featherweight weightlifting category. It was the first of two Olympic appearance by the nation under the Malaya name. He lifted 285 kg (628 lbs), well off his personal best during his prime and finish in 17th place. == Hall of Fame == In 1994, Eng Tong was recognised by the Olympic Council of [http://www.photographermalaysia.my/ Malaysia] and inducted to the Hall of Fame. Mr. Koh presented to Olympic Council of Malaysia (OCM) with a classic photo which he took in the [[1956 Summer Olympics]] in Melbourne. [http://www.olympic.org.my/museum/hof/ind/ket.htm "Iron Man of Malaya"] == 1998 Commonwealth Games == When Kuala Lumpur hosted the [[1998 Commonwealth Games]] Eng Tong was honoured by becoming the [[Queen's Baton Relay]] Final Runner for these games, who at 77 handed the baton which contained the Queen's message to Prince Edward, the Queen's representative and Commonwealth Games Federation president. The games were the first hosted by an Asian country and for the first time in the history of the games that all 70 Commonwealth countries took part. == Personal life == He is survived by his wife, three sons, one daughter, and ten grandchildren. ''Spouse'' - Wong Yoke Lan
''Sons'' - Ronnie Koh, Tony Koh, and Jerry Koh
''Daughter'' - Maureen Chin
''Grandchildren'' - Kevin Koh, Mervin Koh, Tracy Koh, Cindy Koh, Wendy Koh, Malcolm Koh, Patrick Koh, Darren Chin, Sharon Chin, and Brian Chin. {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Koh, Eng Tong}} [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:Malaysian people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:Malaysian male weightlifters]] [[Category:Weightlifters at the 1950 British Empire Games]] [[Category:Weightlifters at the 1956 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic weightlifters of Malaya]] [[Category:Commonwealth Games gold medallists for Malaya]] [[Category:Malaysian businesspeople]] [[Category:Malaysian photographers]] [[Category:Commonwealth Games medallists in weightlifting]]

{{morecat|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Konstantin Dyulgerov | image = Dyulgerovki2.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Konstantin Ivanovich Dyulgerov | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1971|7|27}} | birth_place = [[Izmail]], [[Ukraine]], [[Soviet Union]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | education = | occupation = Russian politician and public figure | known for = | home_town = | salary = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | boards = | children = | parents = | relatives = }}
'''Konstantin Ivanovich Dyulgerov''' (born July 27, 1971 in Izmail) is a Russian entrepreneur, founder of a large retail network, co-owner of realty management companies and other commercial organizations.<ref>Information[https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/3541834 published by КоммерсантЪ (In Russian)]</ref> Dyulgerov is a co-founder of a large Russian travel fares aggregator.
Dyulgerov was put on the international wanted list by Russian law enforcement agencies under the charges of fraud (Article 159 of the Criminal Code) and bribery of witnesses (Article 390 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation).<ref>RIA Novosti. 8 February 2018. (In Russian)[https://ria.ru/incidents/20180208/1514202417.html «Дюльгерова из „списка Титова“ разыскивают по делу о крупном мошенничестве»]</ref>
In February 2018, Dyulgerov, along with the 16 other major Russian businessmen was included in the "Titov's list", compiled by the Russian Presidential Representative for the Rights of Entrepreneurs, Boris Titov. The aim of the list is organizing the return of the entrepreneurs to Russia and reviewing the doubtful criminal cases brought against them.<ref>Russian News Agency TASS. 7 February 2018. (In Russian):[http://tass.ru/ekonomika/4936966 «В список желающих вернуться в Россию из Великобритании бизнесменов вошли 16 человек»]</ref>
Dyulgerov is an active supporter of Russian opposition movement, he participated in several major protest actions. He regularly publicly criticizes the actions of Russian government.<ref name="рупостерс000"> [https://ruposters.ru/news/07-02-2018/biznesmen-zahotel-vernutsya-rossiyu article by Ruposters.ru (In Russian): «Финансировавший протесты на Болотной бизнесмен захотел вернуться в Россию»]</ref>
== Biography == === Early life ===
Konstantin Dyulgerov was born on July 27, 1971, in Izmail, Odessa region, Ukraine. His mother Diana Alexandrovna Dyulgerova worked as a gynecologist, and his father Ivan Ivanovich Dyulgerov was a mechanical engineer.
In 1988 Konstantin Dyulgerov graduated from the secondary school № 7 of the city of Izmail, after which in 1989 he started education in the Izmail Nautical school. However, a year later he entered the Kirovograd Institute of Agricultural Engineering. Upon graduation, he moved to his permanent residence in Nizhnevartovsk, Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Okrug, where he lived for a long time before starting his own business.<ref name="биодюльгеров"> [https://dyulgerov.info/ru/biografiya-ru Autobiography of Dyulgerov K.I. ]</ref>
=== Business career ===
Since the 90s, Konstantin Dyulgerov started growing his business in Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Okrug. He is a founder of several companies working in various areas. In 1996, he founded OOO Konst (retail and wholesale trade in motor vehicles); In 1997, OOO Magnon (real estate management); In 2001, ZAO Samotlor (later OOO Trading Company Samotlor); In 2002 ZAO Special Electronic (real estate management); In 2003 OOO Siberian Industrial Center (Legal activities).
As a result of these business activities, Dyulgerov created the production facilities and an extensive network of stores selling consumer goods: furniture, cosmetics, food, etc. At the same time, Dulgerov's companies owned property like warehouses, production shops, stores. Dyulgerov is also the owner of one of the largest travel fare aggregators in the Russian segment of the Internet.<ref name="биодюльгеров"> [https://dyulgerov.info/ru/biografiya-ru Autobiography of Dyulgerov K.I. ]</ref>
=== Public activity ===
Since 2008, Dyulgerov actively participates in opposition activities and anti-corruption movement. In 2008, Dyulgerov gave his first series of public speeches, in which he exposed and sharply criticized the acting authorities and law enforcement structures of the region. He voiced the accusations of conspiracy, extortion, and corruption, claiming that he refused the offers of "paid protection" suggested by the local law enforcement officials.<ref>Article by mbk.media [https://mbk.media/suzhet/titov-nazval-imena-2/ «Чем известны бизнесмены из „списка Титова“»]</ref> The exposing facts voiced by Dulgerov provoked public resonance in the region.
Later, Dyulgerov actively participated in the various protest movement activities, including the biggest – the March of Millions, a rally on Academician Sakharov Avenue and others. Dyulgerov was providing financial assistance to Russian non-systemic opposition.<ref name="рупостерс000"> [https://ruposters.ru/news/07-02-2018/biznesmen-zahotel-vernutsya-rossiyu article by Ruposters.ru (In Russian): «Финансировавший протесты на Болотной бизнесмен захотел вернуться в Россию»]</ref>
In recent years, Dyulgerov has regularly criticized the authorities on the widely-discussed issues,<ref>K. Dyulgerov's interview to the [http://niros.ru/obschestvo/96161-konstantin-dyulgerov-rossiya-eto-policeysko-banditskoe-gosudarstvo.html «Национальные интересы»]</ref> including the non-admission of Russian athletes to the Olympics,<ref name="рупостерс000"> [https://ruposters.ru/news/07-02-2018/biznesmen-zahotel-vernutsya-rossiyu article by Ruposters.ru (In Russian): «Финансировавший протесты на Болотной бизнесмен захотел вернуться в Россию»]</ref> the failure of import substitution policy and food security, the political and economic structure of Russia.<ref>Konstantin Dyulgerov's [https://dyulgerov.info/en/ personal blog]</ref>
=== Criminal prosecution ===
In 2008, law enforcement authorities launched criminal proceedings against Dyulgerov on suspicion of fraud. In 2010 the case was terminated, however, in 2011 the investigation was resumed. According to the investigation, Konstantin Dyulgerov illegally appropriated the share of Sergey Kiryanov, the second founder of OOO Samotlor Trading Company. After lengthy arbitration proceedings, Kiryanov's 49% share was returned to him. However, the criminal case against Dyulgerov was never terminated.<ref>article by RBK. 7 February 2018. (In Russian):[http://www.interfax.ru/russia/598885 " «Список Титова»: кто из беглых бизнесменов захотел вернуться в Россию ]</ref> It is also known that Sergei Kiryanov is the son-in-law of Nikolai Brykin, ex-general of the Ministry of Internal Affairs and tax police, who is now a deputy of the State Duma from the "United Russia" party.<ref>Official profile of deputy Brykin N.G.[http://www.gosduma.net/structure/deputies/1756768/ on the official website of State Duma of Russian Federation. (In Russian)]</ref>
In 2013, as a result, after receiving charges of fraud, Dyulgerov moved to the United States, as he claimed, to escape the political and criminal persecution. According to Dyulgerov, the said disputed share of Sergei Kiryanov was actually a payment for the enforced "protection". When he refused to pay, they accused him of trying to steal Kiryanov's share. In 2014, another criminal case was launched against him. He is accused of allegedly bribing the witness and compelling him to testify (Article 390 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation). Following this, Dyulgerov was put on the international wanted list. Dyulgerov denies all charges, declaring his innocence.<ref name="биодюльгеров"> [https://dyulgerov.info/ru/biografiya-ru Autobiography of Dyulgerov K.I. ]</ref>
In February 2018, Dyulgerov was included in the "Titov's list" which contains, at the time of publication, the names of 16 businessmen who are being persecuted by Russian law enforcement. According to Boris Titov, the entrepreneurs included in the list were persecuted for dubious reasons, criminal cases against them must be carefully examined and reviewed. The list was submitted to the Administration of the President of Russia, with the official confirmation of its reception and acceptance for consideration.<ref>Information [http://www.interfax.ru/russia/598885 published by Interfax. (In Russian)]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

'''Angela Leong On Kei''' ({{zh|t=梁安琪}}) (born 23 March 1960) is a [[billionaire]] Macau businesswoman, a member of the [[Legislative Council of Macau]], and the fourth wife of [[Stanley Ho]]. ==Early life== Leong was born in [[Guangzhou]], China with family roots in [[Sanshui]], [[Guangdong]].{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} ==Career== As of September 2017, she has an estimated net worth of US$4.1 billion.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/angela-leong/|title=Angela Leong|author=|date=|website=forbes.com|accessdate=20 September 2017}} In September 2017, she bought [[Aldwych House]] in London for about £250 million.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-18/hong-kong-billionaire-is-said-to-buy-338-million-london-office|title=Billionaire Leong Is Said to Buy $338 Million London Office|author=|date=18 September 2017|publisher=|accessdate=20 September 2017|via=www.bloomberg.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/business/hk-billionaire-buys-london-building-for-455m-say-sources|title=HK billionaire buys London building for $455m, say sources|first=|last=hermes|date=20 September 2017|website=straitstimes.com|accessdate=20 September 2017}} ==Personal life== She met her husband-to-be, [[Stanley Ho]], a Macau casino tycoon famous in the political and entertainment industries in Hong Kong and Macau, 40 years her senior, when she was a dance teacher in 1986. She became his fourth "wife" and has four children.{{Citation | title = Stanley Ho "e um mentor", diz Angela Leong | newspaper =[[Jornal Tribuna de Macau]] | issue = 2894 | date = 14 August 2008 | url =http://www.jtm.com.mo/view.asp?dT=289403008|language=pt}} She is the director of the [[Sociedade de Jogos de Macau]],{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/travel/flights/item.aspx?&type=photo&photo_id=09x631r6CA5Pl&pn=12&tid=000000000|title=Travel News, Tips, and Guides - USATODAY.com|author=|date=|website=USA TODAY|accessdate=20 September 2017}} a casino company owned by her husband-to-be, Stanley Ho, since its founding and the managing director since December 2010,{{citation|title=Stanley Ho passes SJM managing director post to Angela Leong|newspaper =The Macau Post Daily|date=31 December 2010|pages=1}} and the vice-chairman of the [[Macau Jockey Club]].{{cite web|url=http://www.destination-macau.com/2007/01/|title=Topics Glossary - South China Morning Post|author=|date=|website=www.destination-macau.com|accessdate=20 September 2017}} With her new appointment as the chairperson of [[Po Leung Kuk]],http://www.poleungkuk.org.hk/en/2009071021/board-of-directors/board-of-directors.html she has also become the [[supervisor]] of [[PLK Vicwood KT Chong Sixth Form College]]. ==Election results== {| class="wikitable" style="margin:0.5em ; font-size:95%" !|Year !|Candidate !|Hare quota !|Mandate !|List Votes !|List Pct |- |[[Macanese legislative '''Mimi Lamote''' (born [[Ostend]], 27 April 1964) is a [[Belgium|Belgian]] businesswoman. Since December 2006, she is the Chair of the Flemish Socio-economic Forum of [[Flanders in Action]] of the [[Flemish government]]. She is a member of the board of [[Belgacom]]. Mimi Lamote is married with Peter Otten and lives in [[Tielrode]].
==Education== She obtained a master in [[economics]] at the [[University of Antwerp]] and a master in Retail Management at the [[Universiteit van Tilburg|Tias University]] of [[Tilburg]].
==Career== From 2001 until 2005, she was General Manager of the [[C&A|C&A Belgium-Luxemburg]] company of the [[Brenninkmeijer family]]. From 2001 until 2004, she was a member of the board of the [[Federation of Belgian Enterprises]] (VBO) and a member of the board of [[Fedis]]. From January 2005 to June 2006, she succeeded [[Etienne Kaesteker]] as CEO of the [[SCF (retailer)|SCF]] retail group comprising ''E5-mode'' and ''Sportorama'' ([[Sint Niklaas]] (Belgium)) and ECG UAB/E5-Mode Baltic UAB/ Edvalda UAB ([[Kaunas]] ([[Lithuania]])).<ref>[http://www.avh.be/Page.aspx?PageID=973 Mimi Lamote, nieuwe CEO van beursgenoteerde SCF]</ref> Since 1 February 2007, she is a member of the management team of ZiekenhuisNetwerk Antwerpen (ZNA), an [[Antwerp]] hospital group.<ref>[http://www.zna.be/Nav%201/Pers/2007/2007%2001%2024%20Mimi%20Lamote.pdf Mimi Lamote versterkt het management van ZNA]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> She is Managing Director of Eugenius BVBA.
On 2 November 2009 she starts as vice-president of [[Pearle Opticians|Pearle Europe]], working at its headquarters in [[Amsterdam]].<ref name="Mimi Lamote">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nieuwsblad.be/Article/Detail.aspx?ArticleID=G6U2GTMTA|title=Mimi Lamote stapt over naar Pearle|accessdate=2009-10-23|publisher=Het Nieuwsblad|year=2009}}</ref>
==References== <references/> * [http://investing.businessweek.com/businessweek/research/stocks/people/person.asppersonId=24917199&capId=4481312&previousCapId=876264&previousTitle=Belgacom%20SA Mimi Lamote]

{{Belgium-business-bio-stub}}

'''Dr. Moritz''' ''(Don Mauricio)'' '''Hochschild''' (1881 in [[Biblis]], [[Germany]] – 1965 in [[Paris]], France) was one of the most famous men in the mining industry in the first half of the twentieth century and was, along with [[Simón Iturri Patiño]] and [[Carlos Víctor Aramayo]], one of the three so-called [[Bolivia]]n [[tin]] barons.<ref>{{cite web | title=The Secret Schindler: Mauricio Hochschild | website=aishcom | date=2017-05-20 | url=http://www.aish.com/ho/p/The-Secret-Schindler-Mauricio-Hochschild.html | access-date=2018-03-10}}</ref> It is now known that he saved Jews during the [[Holocaust]] as well.
==Early life== Hochschild was an [[agnosticism|agnostic]] [[Jew]] whose family had already been active in the mining industry for over a generation. He was the eldest son of a general trader who had two cousins involved in the metal industry: brothers [[Berthold Hochschild]], who founded the [[American Metal Company]] and [[Zachary Hochschild]], a partner in [[Metallgesellschaft]].<ref name=WaszkisReview>{{Cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |title= A Review of Helmut Waszkis' "Dr. Moritz (Don Mauricio) Hochschild 1881-1965. The Man and His Companies. A German ]ewish Mining Entrepreneur in South America|publisher=|date= |url=https://www.mininghistoryassociation.org/Journal/MHJ-v10-2003-Hillman_rev_Waszkis.pdf |accessdate=}}</ref> After Hochschild graduated from school, he studied mining and engineering at the [[Freiberg University of Mining and Technology]].<ref name=papers>[http://findingaids.cjh.org/index2.php?fnm=MoritzHochschild&pnm=LBI Papers of Moritz Hochschild]</ref> In 1905, he began his career in the field at the large industrial conglomerate [[Metallgesellschaft]].<ref name=papers/> and then as the company's agent in [[Spain]] and [[Australia]] and then finally moved to South America to work independently.<ref name=papers/> After several years in [[Chile]], he returned to Germany and stayed there until the end of the [[World War I|first World War]].
==Career== In 1918, he married Käthe Rosenbaum and in 1920, he returned once again to Bolivia. In 1920, his son, Gerardo Hochschild Rosenbaum, was born; his wife died in 1924.<ref name=papers/> During the following two decades, Hochschild built up an economic empire in [[Bolivia]] around the mining and trade of tin ore. His empire stretched from [[Peru]] in the north to [[Chile]] in the south. During this period of growth, more of his family followed him to South America to work for him, including his cousin Philipp Hochschild and Philipp's wife Germaine. Moritz (or Don Mauricio, as he was known in South America) and Germaine had an affair, and they married after Germaine divorced Philipp.<ref name=papers/>
The 1930s saw the peak of the Moritz Hochschild Group's economical and political influence. In 1938, using his influence with [[German Busch]], Bolivia's military president from 1937 to 1939, Hochschild pushed Bolivia to open its doors to Jewish refugees from Hitler's Germany.<ref>{{cite web | title='Bolivian Schindler' saved 9,000 Jews from Nazi Germany | website=Daily Mail Online | date=2017-03-18 | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4326068/Bolivian-Schindler-saved-9-000-Jews-Nazi-Germany.html | access-date=2018-03-10}}</ref> An estimated 9,000 were admitted. Hochschild also funded the transport of the refugees and their housing once they arrived in the South American country. Newspapers have called him "Bolivia's Schindler."
In both 1939 and 1944, Hochschild was arrested by the Bolivian government and sentenced to death.<ref name=papers/> Just two weeks after his release following his 1944 arrest, he was captured and held by kidnappers for two weeks. After he was freed he left Bolivia, never to return.<ref name=papers/>
In 1951, the Hochschilds donated the majority of their fortune to the ''Hochschild Trust and Foundation''. In the following year, the Moritz Hochschild Group was [[Nationalization|nationalized]] during the [[History of Bolivia#Bolivian National Revolution|Bolivian National Revolution]]; however, they were compensated with an allotment of 30% of the company's prior assets.<ref name=papers/> The company, [[Hochschild Mining]], grew further and expanded worldwide. In 1961 Hochschild inaugurated Mantos Blancos copper mine in [[Antofagasta]], [[Chile]], which became his most successful mining operation, although its best results were to come after his death.
==Holocaust Savior== Mauricio Hochschild, who is now being called the 'Bolivian Schindler,'<ref>{{cite web | title=Old files reveal wartime tale of ‘Bolivian Schindler’ | website=Guardian TV | url=https://tv.guardian.ng/news/world-news/old-files-reveal-wartime-tale-of-bolivian-schindler/ | access-date=2018-03-10}}</ref> was a Bolivian business tycoon with a reputation as a 'bad guy' facilitated the escape of at least 9,000 Jews from Nazi Germany as recent documents have revealed. It it now believed that he had strong connections with the Nazi resistance movement, despite being vilified in his time. Moritz Hochschild died in 1965 in [[Paris]].<ref name="foxnews2017">{{cite web | last=Llona | first=Carmen | title='Bolivian Schindler' saved some 9,000 lives during Holocaust, papers show | website=Fox News | date=2017-03-17 | url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/03/17/bolivian-schindler-saved-some-9000-lives-during-holocaust-papers-show.html | access-date=2018-03-10}}</ref> He is the great uncle of billionaire [[Eduardo Hochschild]], who is now the Chairman of Hochschild Mining PLC.<ref>{{cite web | title=Eduardo Hochschild| website=Forbes | url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/eduardo-hochschild/ | access-date=2018-03-10}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://archive.org/details/moritzhochschild Moritz Hochschild Collection 1881-2002] at the Internet Archive
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = PZ Cussons Nigeria plc | logo = | type = Public company | traded_as = | founder = George Paterson, George Zochonis | foundation = | location = [[Lagos]], Nigeria | key_people = Chris Giannopoulos, MD | industry = Cosmetics, [[Soaps]], [[Personal care]], Dairy, [[Household chemicals]], & Natural Oils | products = [[Imperial Leather]], [[Soaps]], Milk, Powdered Milk, [[olive oil]], [[Detergents]] & Healthcare [[Product (business)|Products]]. | revenue = [[Naira]] 79,630m (2017)<ref name="ar"/> | operating_income=[[Naira]] 13,215m<ref name="ar">{{Cite web |url=http://nse.com.ng/Financial_NewsDocs/19494_PZ_CUSSONS-AUDITED_ACCTS_MAY_2017_FINANCIAL_STATEMENTS_SEPTEMBER_2017.pdf |title=PZ Cussons Nigeria PLC 2017 Annual Report}}</ref>(2017) | net_income = | num_employees = | homepage = [https://www.pzcussons.com.ng] }} '''PZ Cussons Nigeria Plc''' is a publicly listed Nigerian manufacturer and distributor of consumer products such as detergents, toiletries, soaps and home appliances. It is a subsidiary of Manchester based [[PZ Cussons|PZ Cussons Holdings]] that owns controlling shares in the firm.
PZ trades home appliances products under the brand [[Haier]] Thermocool and manages Coolworld electrical stores.<ref name="ar"/> It has a joint venture with [[Wilmar International|Wilmar International]] to produce and trade vegetable oil and palm oil.
==History== The company's operations can be traced to the [[Sierra Leone Colony and Protectorate|Sierra Leone]] based commodities and textile dealing partnership of George Paterson and [[George Zochonis]]. The partners who were of Scottish and Greek heritage established a West African trading post in Sierra Leone in 1879 which was later incorporated in Great Britain as Patterson Zochonis in February 1884.<ref>"The Trading Post Company Which Grew and Grew." Manchester: Financial Times Survey. Financial Times, 20 Jan. 1984, p. 19. The Financial Times Historical Archive</ref> In 1899, the partners opened a trading post in Nigeria and soon developed a merchandising network within the country. In the 1950s, the firm began producing soaps in Nigeria from a factory in [[Aba, Nigeria|Aba]],<ref name="cheesebright"/> incorporating it under a subsidiary called Alagbon Industries. In 1957, the group transferred assets not affiliated with its soap business to a newly incorporated company in Nigeria called Patterson Zochonis Nigeria Limited. Alagbon industries was later known as Associated Industries and then changed to Paterson Zochonis Industries Limited.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://thenationonlineng.net/pz-nigeria-plc-continuing-its-winning-streak/ |title=PZ Nigeria Plc: Continuing its winning streak - The Nation Nigeria |date=2014-10-08 |work=The Nation Nigeria |access-date=2018-07-29 |language=en-US}}</ref> It became publicly listed on the [[Nigerian Stock Exchange]] in 1972, selling 40% of its shares to the Nigerian public, a further 60% was sold in 1977.
The group expanded to include Thermocool appliances.<ref>"Paterson, Zochonis & Company LTD." Financial Times, 8 Nov. 1957, p. 4. The Financial Times Historical Archive, </ref> PZ industries concentrated on toiletries, soaps and detergents manufacturing and Thermocool focused on refrigerators. PZ expanded its manufacturing business and commenced production of Elephant and Jet detergents in 1970s to challenge [[Omo (detergent)|Omo]] produced by Lever Brothers.<ref name="cheesebright">Financial Times (London, England), Nigeria: Financial Times Survey. Tuesday, November 30, 1982, Issue 28,939, p.XXVII</ref> In 1973, Thermocool refrigerators were assembled in Nigeria and the company invested in pharmaceutical manufacturing. The firm reduced its trading activities during the 1970s.
In 2003, the firm launched a joint venture with [[Glanbia|Glanbia group]] to produce evaporated milk and milk powder.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.just-food.com/news/glanbia-quits-pz-cussons-nigeria-venture_id129638.aspx |title=Glanbia quits PZ Cussons Nigeria venture |date=2015-04-01 |access-date=2018-07-29}}</ref>
==Brands== *Ava *Canoe *Elephant *Florish *Joy *MORNIING FRESH *Nunu *Premier *Robb *Stella *Sweet 16 *Haier Thermocool *Venus *Venus de Milo
==History== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
A '''periodization of capitalism''' seeks to distinguish stages of development that help understanding of features of [[capitalism]] through time. The best-known periodizations that have been proposed distinguish these stages as:
#Early or concurrential/ [[monopoly]]/ [[state monopoly capitalism]] ([[Paul Sweezy|Sweezy]] etc.) #Free trade/ monopoly/ [[finance capitalism]] ([[Rudolf Hilferding|Hilferding]] etc.) #Early capitalism ([[primitive accumulation]])/ [[colonialism]]/ [[imperialism]] ([[John A. Hobson|Hobson]], Lenin, Bukharin) #[[Extensive stage]]/ [[intensive stage]]/ ([[late capitalism]]) ([[Michel Aglietta|Aglietta]])
The [[Marxist]] periodization of capitalism into the stages:<ref>Rutherford, Donald. Routledge Dictionary of Economics. pages 70</ref> agricultural capitalism, [[merchant capitalism]], industrial capitalism and [[state capitalism]].
Another periodization includes [[merchant capitalism]], industrial and [[finance capitalism]], and [[global capitalism]].<ref>Dunning, John H. global capitalism at bay? pages 49</ref><ref>Dunning, John H. Making Globalization Good. pages 181</ref> <ref>Davis Jerome. Capitalism and Its Culture. page 12</ref>
==See also== *[[Rudolf Hilferding]] *[[Ernest Mandel]] *[[Paul Sweezy]]
==References== *Aglietta, Michel, ''Régulation et crises du capitalisme'', Kalmann-Lévy, Paris, 1976 {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1916/imp-hsc/ Imperialism: The Highest Stage of Capitalism by V.I. Lenin]
[[Category:Capitalism]]

{{About|the suburb of Perth, Western Australia|the local government area|City of Perth|the metropolitan area|Perth}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox Australian place | type = suburb | name = Perth | city = Perth | state = wa | image = The Perth skyline in January 2016.jpg | caption = Perth central business district | image_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|31.95|S|115.85|E|display=inline,title}} | alternative_location_map = Australia Western Australia metropolitan Perth | relief = | pushpin_label_position = | map_alt = | pop = 11,425 | pop_year = {{CensusAU|2016}} | pop_footnotes = {{Census 2016 AUS|id=SSC51218|name=Perth (WA) (State Suburb)|accessdate=19 April 2018|quick=on}} | poprank = | density = | density_footnotes = | established = 1829 | abolished = | gazetted = | postcode = 6000 | elevation = | elevation_footnotes = | area = | area_footnotes = | timezone = | utc = | timezone-dst = | utc-dst = | dist1 = | dir1 = | location1 = | lga = [[City of Perth]]
[[City of Vincent]] | region = | county = | stategov = [[Electoral district of Perth|Perth]] | fedgov = [[Division of Perth|Perth]] | url = | maxtemp = | maxtemp_footnotes = | mintemp = | mintemp_footnotes = | rainfall = | rainfall_footnotes = | near = | near-n = [[North Perth, Western Australia|North Perth]] | near-ne = [[Highgate, Western Australia|Highgate]] | near-e = [[East Perth, Western Australia|East Perth]] | near-se = [[Victoria Park, Western Australia|Victoria Park]] | near-s = [[South Perth, Western Australia|South Perth]] | near-sw = [[West Perth, Western Australia|West Perth]] | near-w = [[Northbridge, Western Australia|Northbridge]] | near-nw = [[North Perth, Western Australia|North Perth]] | established_footnotes = | footnotes = }} '''Perth''' is a [[List of Perth suburbs|suburb]] in [[Western Australia]] that includes both the [[Perth CBD|central business district]] of the [[Perth|Perth metropolitan area]],{{cite web|url=http://www.landgate.wa.gov.au/docvault.nsf/web/PS_FREEMAP/$FILE/Perth_Inner_Metro_Mosaic.pdf|title=Free Maps – Perth Inner – Metropolitan|year=2008|publisher=[[Landgate]]|accessdate=10 April 2012}} and a suburban area spreading north to the northern side of [[Hyde Park, Western Australia|Hyde Park]]. It does not include the separate suburbs of [[Northbridge, Western Australia|Northbridge]] or [[Highgate, Western Australia|Highgate]]. Perth is split between the [[City of Perth]] and the [[City of Vincent]] local authorities. Perth was named after the [[Perth, Scotland|city of the same name]] in Scotland.{{cite web|url=https://www0.landgate.wa.gov.au/maps-and-imagery/wa-geographic-names/name-history/historical-suburb-names#P|title=History of Metropolitan Suburb Names|publisher=[[Landgate]]|accessdate=10 April 2012}} == Built environment == The dominant land use in Perth is commercial. Office buildings include [[108 St Georges Terrace]], [[QV.1]], [[Brookfield Place (Perth)|Brookfield Place]] and [[Central Park, Perth|Central Park]] – the tallest building in the city and the [[List of tallest buildings in Australia|eighth tallest in Australia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.central-park.com.au/Public/home.asp|title=Home|publisher=Central Park|accessdate=29 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503175038/http://www.central-park.com.au/Public/home.asp|archivedate=3 May 2009|df=dmy-all}} === Significant buildings === [[File:Perth Council House.jpg|thumb|200px|left|[[Council House, Perth]]]] The [[Perth Town Hall]], built between 1868 and 1870, was designed as an administrative centre for the newly formed [[City of Perth]]. By the late 1950s the Town Hall was considered too small for the council's requirements so [[Council House, Perth|Council House]], a [[Modern architecture|modernist]] steel and glass building, was commissioned. Completed in 1960, Council House has divided opinions over its architectural merit.{{cite web|url=http://register.heritage.wa.gov.au/PDF_Files/C%20-%20A-D/02097%20Council%20House%20(I-AD).PDF|title=Register of Heritage Places – Assessment Documentation – Council House|publisher=[[Heritage Council of Western Australia]]|accessdate=29 April 2009}} Both the Town Hall and Council House are on the [[Register of the National Estate]].{{cite web|url=http://register.heritage.wa.gov.au/comprehensivereport.html?place_seq=2097|title=Places Database – Council House, Perth|publisher=[[Heritage Council of Western Australia]]|accessdate=29 April 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://register.heritage.wa.gov.au/comprehensivereport.html?place_seq=1953|title=Places Database – Perth Town Hall|publisher=[[Heritage Council of Western Australia]]|accessdate=29 April 2009}} == Demographics == Perth has a residential population of 6,341. Residents of Perth are drawn from a number of backgrounds – 40% of the population were born in [[Australia]] with minorities from [[England]] (6.5%), [[New Zealand]] (2.4%), [[Malaysia]] (2.1%), [[Vietnam]] (2.1%) and [[Italy]] (1.9%).{{Census 2011 AUS |id=SSC50639 |name=State Suburbs: Perth |accessdate=4 July 2012 |quick=on}} == Arts and culture == The [[Perth Cultural Centre]] includes facilities such as the [[Art Gallery of Western Australia]], the [[State Library of Western Australia]], the [[State Theatre Centre of Western Australia]] and the [[Western Australian Museum]].{{cite web|url=http://www.perth.wa.gov.au/our-city/things-see-and-do/attractions|title=Attractions|publisher=[[City of Perth]]|accessdate=15 February 2014}} The [[Perth Concert Hall, Western Australia|Perth Concert Hall]] is located on [[St Georges Terrace]] and [[His Majesty's Theatre, Perth|His Majesty's Theatre]] on [[Hay Street, Perth|Hay Street]]. == Transport == Three freeways service the suburb – [[Mitchell Freeway]], [[Kwinana Freeway]] and [[Graham Farmer Freeway]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mainroads.wa.gov.au/UsingRoads/RoadTrafficInformation/Pages/RoadTrafficInformation.aspx|title=Main Roads Metropolitan Road Fact Sheet |publisher=[[Main Roads Western Australia]]|accessdate=29 April 2009}} Public transport facilities include three train stations ([[Perth railway station]], [[McIver railway station]], [[Elizabeth Quay railway station]]) and two bus stations ([[Elizabeth Quay Bus Station]] and [[Perth Busport]]), as well as the East Perth Terminal, servicing intrastate and interstate rail and bus services.{{cite web|url=http://www.transperth.wa.gov.au/Default.aspx?tabid=362&id=100|title=Transperth Network Map – Sheet 4 |publisher=[[Transperth]]|accessdate=29 April 2009}} The [[Elizabeth Quay Jetty]] is the home of [[Transperth]] ferry services. Perth is served by four free [[Perth Central Area Transit|Central Area Transit]] (CAT) bus routes and a number of open and high rise public car parks.{{cite web|url=http://reiwa.com/res/res-suburb-profile.cfm?suburb_id=2707&census_code=SSC52156&geogroup_id=2171&geogroup_parent_id=3|title=Perth Suburb Profiles – Perth|publisher=REIWA|accessdate=29 April 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cityofperth.wa.gov.au/citymaps/map_basic.html|title=City of Perth Parking|publisher=[[City of Perth]]|accessdate=29 April 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.transperth.wa.gov.au/Default.aspx?tabid=362&id=100|title=Perth CAT map |publisher=[[Transperth]]|accessdate=29 April 2009}} == Streets == The main east-west streets through the city block are St Georges Terrace, Hay Street, [[Murray Street, Perth|Murray Street]] and [[Wellington Street, Perth|Wellington Street]]. The main north-south streets are [[Barrack Street]] and [[William Street, Perth|William Street]]. Five streets have had sections converted to pedestrian malls: Murray Street, Hay Street, [[James Street, Northbridge|James Street]], Museum Street and [[Forrest Place]]. == Sport == Sporting facilities include [[Perth Oval]], the home ground of association football (soccer) team [[Perth Glory]] and [[Super Rugby]] team [[Western Force]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nibstadium.com.au/teams|title=Teams|publisher=nib stadium|accessdate=12 May 2012}} Between 1910 and 1999 it was the home of [[Australian rules football]] team [[East Perth Football Club|East Perth]]. At the western end of Wellington Street is the [[Perth Arena]], an indoor stadium designed to host indoor sports such as tennis and basketball.{{cite web|url=http://www.dhw.wa.gov.au/pertharena/index.html|title=Perth Arena|publisher=Department of Treasury and Finance, WA|accessdate=29 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090519013850/http://www.dhw.wa.gov.au/pertharena/index.html|archivedate=19 May 2009|df=dmy-all}} The [[Perth Entertainment Centre]], which was located adjacent to the new Arena, was the home court for the [[Perth Wildcats]] between 1990 and 2002. Tennis clubs are located at Robertson Park and Loton Park. == References == {{wikivoyage|Perth/City|Perth City suburb}} {{Reflist|30em}} {{City of Perth suburbs}} {{Town of Vincent suburbs}} {{Capital city central business districts of Australia}} [[Category:Suburbs of Perth, Western Australia]] [[Category:Central business districts in Australia]]
