{{Infobox comedian | name = Tado | image = Tado.png | caption = Tado in 2009 | birth_name = Arvin Impuesto Jimenez | birth_date = {{birth date|1974|3|24}} | birth_place = [[Baybay, Leyte]], Philippines | death_date = {{Death date and age|2014|2|7|1974|3|24}} | death_place = [[Bontoc, Mountain Province]], Philippines | origin = [[Marikina]], Metro Manila, Philippines | medium = Stand-up, television, radio, internet | other_names = | known_for = ''[[Taylor Swift]]'' | occupation = Comedian, radio personality, activist, published author | genre =[[Satire]]/[[political satire]]/[[news satire]], [[observational comedy]] | subject =[[Mass media]]/[[news media]]/[[media criticism]], [[politics of the Philippines|Philippines politics]], [[human sexuality]], [[self-deprecation]] |spouse = Lei Jimenez | yearsactive = 2001–2014 }} '''Arvin Jimenez''' (March 24, 1974 – February 7, 2014), known [[mononym]]ously as '''Tado''', was a Filipino comedian, actor, radio personality, businessman, published author and activist. His nickname "Tado" comes from a [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] expletive he frequently blurts out.<ref name="Times">{{cite news |first=Perry Gil |last=Mallari |title=Tado Jimenez seriously |url=http://www.manilatimes.net/national/2008/sep/07/yehey/weekend/20080907week1.html |work=[[The Manila Times]] |date=2008-09-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090830060731/http://www.manilatimes.net/national/2008/sep/07/yehey/weekend/20080907week1.html |archivedate=2009-08-30 |df= }}</ref> Tado was primarily known for the offbeat television program ''[[Strangebrew]]'' and the [[DWFM|U92]] radio program ''The BrewRATs!''.
==Early life and career== Prior to fame, Tado had worked on various odd jobs such as a staff in a mental hospital, a [[waiter]], a [[scriptwriter]] for television and a [[photojournalist]]. Tado graduated from the [[Polytechnic University of the Philippines]] (PUP) with a degree in [[Psychology]]. He was an active member of Scouts Royale Brotherhood (SRB) International Service Fraternity and Sorority under the waving banner of Beta Tau Chapter. He was engaged in social issues as a student organizer of [[Sanlakas party-list|Sanlakas]].<ref name="Times"/>
While in PUP, Tado was influenced by his artist friends, causing him to be involved in theater, painting and photography. This led to the founding of the now-defunct PUP-based cultural organization called PANDAY PIRA (Pandayan ng Pilipinong Kultura). He eventually studied film making at the [[Mowelfund Institute]].<ref name="Times"/>
Tado later co-founded Dakila ("Noble"), an artists group aiming to instill modern-day heroism in everyday people, with poet [[Lourd de Veyra]], bassist for [[Parokya ni Edgar]], [[Buwi Meneses]] and acclaimed actor, [[Ronnie Lazaro]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Agimat Launches a Central Website for Filipino Artists|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/sosy/sosy/view/20080807-153224/Agimat-Launches-a-Central-Website-for-Filipino-Artists|work=[[The Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=2008-08-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091001033951/http://globalnation.inquirer.net/sosy/sosy/view/20080807-153224/Agimat-Launches-a-Central-Website-for-Filipino-Artists|archivedate=2009-10-01|df=}}</ref>
Tado also dabbled in music, and had appeared with the band [[The Youth (band)|The Youth]] as their lead vocalist with original vocalist Dodong Cruz's consent. He and the band appeared on the [[GMA Network]] program ''[[Unang Hirit]]'', singing the band's hit "''Multong Bakla''" ("gay ghost").<ref>{{cite news|title=The Youth (?) |url=http://www.unanghirit.tv/?p=630 |work=Unanghirit.tv |date=2008-09-27}}</ref>
==Strangebrew== Tado became involved in television with the premiere of the off-the-wall magazine show ''[[Strangebrew]]'' in the then-[[NU 107]] operated [[DWAO-TV|UNTV Channel 37]], with Angel Rivero as his co-host, in 2001. His maroon [[Volkswagen Beetle]] took him and Rivero throughout Metro Manila on an adventure with "a unique cartoony look, a caustic wit" with "a weird sense of humor."<ref name="Times"/>
Strangebrew and Tado became a cult hit until the show was canceled a year later, with him enshrined as a pop culture icon.<ref name="Times"/>
In almost all episodes whenever they interview a certain person, Tado throws his famous question ''"Kuya/ate, sa tagal mo nang ginagawa itong trabaho na ito, umibig ka na ba?"''
==The BrewRATs!== He was reunited with Rivero (along with occasional ''Strangebrew'' contributor, [[Ramon Bautista]]) in [[DWRT-FM|Hit 99.5 FM]] (now 99.5 Play FM's) late night talk show ''The BrewRATs!''<ref name="Times"/> in which is a pun on the Tagalog slang of the male genitalia. Even with Hit FM's reformatting to 99.5 Campus FM and finally reverting to its old 99.5 RT callsign, the show was consistently placed on the station's roster of shows, and consistently occupying the late night slot until it was moved to the morning slot from August to September 2009.
On October 1, 2009, ''The BrewRATs!'' resurfaced on [[DWFM|U92]], the radio affiliate of [[MTV Philippines]], of which Bautista was a personality of (''The Ramon Bautista Show''). It went off the air a second time as a result of U92's reformat to Radyo5 92.3 News FM and has since become a show at the internet radio station DigRadio every Thursday from 9 PM to midnight.<ref>http://pinoytuner.com/article/191/the-brewrats-are-coming {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110824123156/http://pinoytuner.com/article/191/the-brewrats-are-coming |date=August 24, 2011 }}</ref><ref>http://pinoytuner.com/popout/192/watch-brewrats {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110824123346/http://pinoytuner.com/popout/192/watch-brewrats |date=August 24, 2011 }}</ref>
==LimiTado== Aside from radio, Tado also designed ''LimiTado'' ("Limited"), and ran it with his wife. The graphic [[T-shirt]]s' main selling points are striking messages printed on the shirt and spoofs. Other items include bags, accessories and toy collectibles such as Volkswagen die-casts.<ref>{{cite news |first=Pam |last=Pastor |title=The gospel of Tado’s T-shirts |url=http://showbizandstyle.inquirer.net/you/2bu/view/20070717-77169/The_gospel_of_Tado%92s_T-shirts |work=INQUIRER.net |date=2007-07-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120717234910/http://showbizandstyle.inquirer.net/you/2bu/view/20070717-77169/The_gospel_of_Tado%92s_T-shirts |archivedate=2012-07-17 |df= }}</ref> He also has a [[tattoo]] shop.
==Political life== Tado [[Marikina local elections, 2010#District 1|ran for the position of city councilor]] of Marikina's 1st District (coextensive with [[Legislative districts of Marikina City#1st District|Marikina's 1st congressional district]]) in 2010 as an [[independent (politician)|independent candidate]]. He finished eleventh; the first eight in the tally were elected.
Tado was involved in protest actions of the [[Sanlakas party-list|Sanlakas]] political bloc such as the campaign against rising electricity rates,<ref>[http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2012/11/26/873735/congress-urged-repeal-epira-law Congress urged to repeal EPIRA law | Headlines, News, The Philippine Star | philstar.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and demonstrations against [[Constitutional reform in the Philippines|Charter Change]].<ref>[http://www.inquirer.net/specialreports/inquirerpolitics/view.php?db=1&article=20090610-209768 INQUIRER Politics<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606002722/http://www.inquirer.net/specialreports/inquirerpolitics/view.php?db=1&article=20090610-209768 |date=2013-06-06 }}</ref> He also supported the picket protest of the workers of Philippine Airlines.<ref>[http://hronlineph.com/2011/11/27/press-release-tado-mag-eemcee-sa-concert-para-sa-palea/ [Press Release] Tado mag-eemcee sa concert para sa PALEA | Human Rights Online Philippines<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He was also seen visiting Sulu Sultan [[Jamalul Kiram III]], expressing his support in the [[2013 Lahad Datu standoff|Sulu Sultanate's claim]] over [[North Borneo dispute|Sabah, North Borneo]]. He also joined the demonstration against the [[Priority Development Assistance Fund]], known as [[Priority Development Assistance Fund scam|Pork barrel]].
Tado ran again for the position of [[Marikina local elections, 2013#District 1|city councilor]] of Marikina's 1st District in 2013 as a candidate under [[Partido Lakas ng Masa]]. This would be the second time he lost in the election, finishing at eleventh yet again.
== Death ==
Tado died on February 7, 2014 in an [[2014 Mountain Province Bus Accident|accident]] when a [[GV Florida Transport]] bus fell off a road in Sitio Paggang, [[Talubin]], [[Bontoc, Mountain Province|Bontoc]], [[Mountain Province]] in the [[Philippines]].<ref>http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/347387/news/regions/comedian-tado-among-14-dead-in-bus-crash-in-mt-province</ref> In total, fourteen people were killed and more than 32 people were injured.
==Selected filmography==
===Television=== *''[[Strangebrew]]'' as himself (UNTV 37, 2001–02) *[[Pangako Sa 'Yo]] as Jason (ABS-CBN, 2000) *''[[Bituin]]'' as King (ABS-CBN, 2002) *''Klasmeyts'' (ABS-CBN, 2002) *''[[Magandang Tanghali Bayan|Masayang Tanghali Bayan]]'' as himself (Host) (ABS-CBN, 2003–04) *''[[Ok Fine 'To Ang Gusto Nyo|Ok Fine Whatever]]'' (ABS-CBN, 2003) *''[[Magandang Tanghali Bayan|MTB: Ang Saya Saya]]'' (ABS-CBN, 2004–2005) *''[[Art Jam]]'' as host (ABS-CBN, 2005) *''Laugh To Laugh: Ang Kulit'' (Q, 2005) *''[[Project 11]]'' (Q, 2006) *''[[Baywalk]]'' (Q, 2006) *''Camera Cafe Philippine Edition'' as himself (Q, 2007; GMA Network, 2007–08) *''[[Palos (TV series)|Palos]]'' (ABS-CBN, 2008) *''The Weekend News With Ramon Bautista'' (TV5, 2009) as himself/guest *''[[Pinoy Big Brother]]'' as himself (ABS-CBN, 2009) *''Stoplight TV'' (TV5, 2009) *''[[Maynila (TV series)|Maynila]]'' (GMA Network, 2010) *''[[Showtime (Philippines)|Showtime]]'' as himself (Judge) (ABS-CBN, 2010) *''[[Eat Bulaga]]'' as Himself/Guest (GMA Network, 2010) *''30w POwhz!'' as Himself (Studio 23, 2010) *''[[Happy Yipee Yehey!]]'' as Himself (ABS-CBN, 2011) *''[[Wasak]]'' as Himself (AKSYON TV, 2013) *''[[Pepito Manaloto]]'' as Driver (GMA, 2013) *''One Day Isang Araw presents "John Tamad"'' (GMA, 2013) *''[[Pinoy True Stories|My Puhunan]]'' as himself on his business '''LimiTADO''' (2014, [[List of works published posthumously|air posthumously]]) *''[[Day Off (TV series)|Day Off]]'' as himself (2014, [[List of works published posthumously|air posthumously]]) *''AHA!'' as himself (GMA, 2013-2014) <small>''His last TV appearance''</small>
===Film=== *''Radio'' (2001) *''Trip'' (2001) *''Hesus, Rebolusyunaryo'' (2002) *''Utang Ni Tatang'' (2002) *''First Time'' (2003) *''Astigmatism'' (2004) *''Dilim'' (2005) *''Boso'' (2005) *''[[D' Anothers]]'' (2005) as Atty. Reposo *''Coup Betat'' (2006) *''M.O.N.A.Y (Misteyks obda neyson adres Yata) ni Mr. Shooli'' (2007) *''Scaregivers'' (2008) *''69{{frac|1|2}} (2009) *''Ang Beerhouse (2009) *''Captive (2012) *''PakantoTADO (2012) *''Dyagwar: Havey O Waley (2012) *''[[Call Center Girl]] (2013) *''[[My Little Bossings]] (2013) <small>''Final Appearance with [[Vic Sotto]] and [[Kris Aquino]]''</small>
===Music Videos=== *"Nerbyoso" by Rivermaya (cameo) *"Harana" by Parokya Ni Edgar (cameo) *"Picha Pie" by Parokya Ni Edgar *"Swimming Beach" by Parokya Ni Edgar *"Boy Kulot" by Rocksteddy *"Ang Parokya" by Parokya Ni Edgar (stock footage) *"Magkabilang Mundo" by Jireh Lim (love triangle with [[Donnalyn Bartolome]]) *"Maquilit" by Q-York Feat. Sponge Cola (posthimous released video)

{{Infobox person | name = Thomas Bilyeu | image = Tom Bilyeu.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Tom Bilyeu, 2017 | birth_name = | residence = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S. | nationality = [[United States|American]] | birth_place = [[Tacoma, Washington|Tacoma]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], U.S. | alma_mater = [[University of Southern California]] | known_for = Entrepreneurship, Keynote Speaking, Mindset | occupation = Co-Founder/CEO Impact Theory
Co-Founder Quest Nutrition
Host, Inside Quest
Host, Impact Theory | salary = | networth = $400 million | spouse = | children = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = {{url|http://www.impacttheory.com/}} }} '''Thomas Bilyeu''' (born 1976) is an American [[entrepreneur]] best known as a co-founder of [[Quest Nutrition]], the second-fastest-growing private company in North America on the [[Inc 500|Inc 5000]] for 2014.{{cite web|title=Profile: Quest Nutrition|url=http://www.inc.com/profile/quest-nutrition|publisher=Inc}}{{cite web|last1=Forbes|first1=Miguel|title=Quest Nutrition Co-Founder: We Grew By 57,000% In Our First 3 Years|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/miguelforbes/2016/02/22/quest-nutrition-cofounder-we-grew-by-57000-in-our-first-3-years/#174bac9f1511|publisher=Forbes}}{{cite web|title=The quest to healthier snacks|url=http://video.cnbc.com/gallery/?video=3000382288|publisher=CNBC}} He was born and raised in [[Tacoma, Washington]].{{cite web|title=Inside Quest|url=http://www.insidequest.com/author/tbilyeu/|accessdate=9 January 2017}} Bilyeu is also a board member on [[Peter Diamandis]]'s [[X Prize Foundation]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.xprize.org/benefactors/innovation-board/tom-bilyeu|title=Tom Bilyeu|date=2016-04-19|work=XPRIZE|access-date=2017-06-29|language=en}} ==Quest Nutrition== Bilyeu co-founded Quest Nutrition in 2010 alongside [[Ron Penna]] and [[Mike Osborn (entrepreneur)|Mike Osborn]].{{cite web|last1=Foster|first1=Tom|title=Building a Company the Hard Way|url=http://www.inc.com/magazine/201409/tom-foster/inc.500-companies-who-bootrapped-their-way-to-success.html|publisher=Inc}}{{cite web|last1=Yi|first1=Jae|title=5 Lessons on Chasing Your Dreams From Tom Bilyeu|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jae-yi/5-lessons-on-chasing-your_b_8694778.html|publisher=Huffington Post}} The company grew by 57,000% in its first 3 years, and was ranked #2 on the [[Inc 500]] fastest-growing companies in the United States in 2014. By 2013 the company employed over 200 people and had revenue over $82 million. By the end of 2015, Quest was sold at over 40,000 points of distribution in over 70 countries. As of 2016, Quest Nutrition employed 1,300 full-time employees and over 1,000 part-time ambassadors.{{cite web|last1=Lewis|first1=Howes|title=How to be a Jedi and Master The Mind with Tom Bilyeu of Quest Nutrition|url=http://lewishowes.com/podcast/tom-bilyeu/|publisher=Lewis Howes}} Bilyeu has said his goal with Quest Nutrition was to end metabolic disease and show that food can be "good for you and still taste good".{{cite web|last1=Watrous|first1=Monica|title=How this protein bar brand grew 57,000% in three years|url=http://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/news_home/Business_News/2015/09/How_this_protein_bar_brand_gre.aspx?ID=%7BF3E0731D-0F8E-4544-B09B-D7100A35D87B%7D&cck=1|publisher=Food Business News}} ==Impact Theory== In October 2016 Bilyeu and his wife, Lisa, started Impact Theory, a for-profit media company designed to "leverage the self-sustaining power of commerce to radically influence global culture."{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@TomBilyeu/why-we-founded-impact-theory-2da099df5db3|title=Why We Founded Impact Theory|last=Bilyeu|first=Tom|date=2017-01-05|website=Tom Bilyeu|access-date=2017-06-29}} Impact Theory has a 3-stage business plan: Stage 1: Community Building. Stage 2: Incubation. Stage 3: Building and Selling.{{Cite web|url=http://impacttheory.com/about/|title=Impact Theory Mission, Mindset, & Team {{!}} Impact Theory|website=impacttheory.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-29}} As of July 2018, Impact Theory is still in its first stage with over 1,500,000 followers on its social media platforms. Impact Theory publishes a long-form interview talk show, hosted by Bilyeu, with guests like [[Peter Diamandis]], [[Wyclef Jean]], [[Jason Silva]], [[Laila Ali]], [[Terrell Owens]], [[Drew Pinsky|Dr. Drew]], [[Michael Strahan]], [[John Paul DeJoria]], [[Gary Vaynerchuk]], [[Mel Robbins]] and [[Tim Ferriss]]. [[File:Tom Bilyeu Interview Peter D.jpg|thumb|With [[Peter Diamandis]]]] ==References== {{Reflist|40em}} ==External links== *[http://www.questnutrition.com/ Quest Nutrition] *[http://www.insidequest.com/ Inside Quest] *[http://www.impacttheory.com/ Impact Theory] {{DEFAULTSORT:Bilyeu, Thomas}} [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Tacoma, Washington]] [[Category:1976 births]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} A '''web presence''' is a location on the [[World Wide Web]] where a person, business, or some other entity is represented (see also [[web property]] and [[point of presence]]).
Examples of a web presence for a person could be a personal [[website]], a [[blog]], a profile page, a wiki page, or a [[social media]] [[point of presence]] (e.g. a LinkedIn profile, a Facebook account, or a Twitter account). Examples of a web presence for a business or some other entity could be a corporate website, a [[microsite]], a page on a review site, a wiki page, or a social media point of presence (e.g., a LinkedIn company page and/or group, a Facebook business/brand/product page, or a Twitter account).
Every web presence is associated with a unique [[web address]] to distinguish one point of presence from another.
==Owned vs. unowned== Web presence can either be owned or unowned. [[Earned media|Owned media]] exists when a single person or group can control the content that is published on its web presence (e.g. a corporate website or a personal Twitter account). However, when a single person or group cannot solely control the content, the creator is different from the owner. This is considered unowned media (see [[earned media]]). A Wikipedia or Yelp page about a person, company, or product would be an example of an unowned (or "earned") web presence.
Occasionally, a third form of media known as "paid media" is often included in the discussion of media types: "earned vs. owned vs. paid". Paid media is commonly found in the form of advertisements, but it is not considered a form of web presence.
==Management== Web presence management is the process of establishing and maintaining a digital footprint on the web. The three factors that are considered include the following: ''where'' a person or business has web presence; ''how'' each web presence represents its enterprise; and ''what'' is published at a point of presence.
Web presence management is the discipline of determining and governing: * the distribution of policy documents * which platforms are most appropriate (e.g. internal vs. external blog, YouTube vs. Vimeo) * the single inventory of personal or corporate web presence (e.g. partners or advocates) * where on the web a business and any relatable assets are represented * where on the web a business and any relatable assets are impersonated or pirated * web properties with the particular entities they represent * who has control over which web properties * new web properties which are not in the personal or corporate inventory (e.g. someone creates a new presence) * authorized and unauthorized changes to the creation (e.g. branding) of a web presence * a workflow for creating a web property that follows its corporate standards
===Management system=== The purpose of a web presence management system is to manage the web presence of a person or business. This includes the collection of domain names, websites, social media, and other web pages where he, she, or it is being represented. The tool generally offers the following key functions: new presence discovery, inventory management, change detection, access control, stakeholder coordination, and compliance workflow.
A web presence management system is meant to have a broader reach so that it emphasizes where a presence has been established, will be established, must be maintained, or must be remediated. An example of a web presence management system is the Brandle Presence Manager.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Roberson|first1=Chip|url=http://www.brandle.net/blog/2013/11/social-presence-vs-social-content|title=Social Content vs. Social Presence - Don't neglect your social footprint|publisher=Brandle, Inc.|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref>
In order to publish content to the various points of web presence, multiple [[content management system]]s and sometimes even [[social media]] [[management system]]s are often used. The primary focus of most content and social media management systems is limited to their specific web platforms.
===Domain names=== Another aspect of web presence management is managing the collection of [[domain name]]s registered to the person or business. Any entity may register multiple domain names for the same property. As a result, they can link alternative spellings, different [[top-level domain]]s, aliases, brands, or products to the same website. Similarly, negative or derogatory domain names may also be registered. This is done to prevent certain domain names from being used against the person or business.
It is common for a larger business to have domain names registered by multiple employees at multiple [[domain name registrar]]s, possibly a result of organizational or geographical requirements. Consequently, a web presence management system can be used to monitor all domain names registered by the business, regardless of the registrars used.
==Discovery== Web presence discovery is the process of monitoring the web for a new point of presence about a person or business. Web presence discovery is often included in a web presence management system. Whether a new domain is registered, a new website is published, or a new social media account is established, it occurs outside of the person’s or business’ control. As a result, its purpose is to assess a new point of presence and appropriately handle any violations.
It is important to note that web presence discovery differs from content listening. The former involves looking for new properties on the web, whereas the latter refers to analyzing content that already exists to hear how a person or business is seen often in near real time. Examples of content listening systems include [[Sysomos]] and Radian6, which is now a subsidiary of [[Salesforce.com]].
===Brand protection=== A person or business may choose to watch for a new web presence that might appear to misrepresent or mislead an audience, such as counterfeiters, spoofers, or malicious hackers. One of the early software in the online brand protection marketplace was [[MarkMonitor]], now part of [[Thomson Reuters]]. This software helped detect rogue domain names and websites.
However, the modern day growth of social media has seen a rise in the number of fraudulent brand impersonations. It has become much easier for a new web presence to be created on those platforms, which results in a greater frequency of them today.<ref>{{cite web|title=Reputation@Risk - 2014 global survey on reputation risk|url=http://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/global/Documents/Governance-Risk-Compliance/gx_grc_Reputation@Risk%20survey%20report.pdf|website=Deloitte|publisher=Deloitte|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{cite web|title=Global Risk Management Survey 2015|url=http://www.aon.com/2015GlobalRisk/default.jsp|website=AON|publisher=AON|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref><ref name="17th Annual Global CEO Survey">{{cite web|title=17th Annual Global CEO Survey|url=http://read.pwc.com/i/243985-pwcs-17th-annual-global-ceo-survey|website=PwC|publisher=PwC|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ey.com/US/en/Issues/Governance-and-reporting/Audit-Committee/BoardMatters-Quarterly---April-2014---4---The-business-of-social-media |title=BoardMatters Quarterly, April 2014 - The business of social media - EY - United States |publisher=EY |date= |accessdate=2018-09-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Board Matters Quarterly - Critical insights for today’s audit committee|url=http://www.ey.com/Publication/vwLUAssets/EY_-_Board_Matters_Quarterly,_April_2014/$FILE/ey-BMQ-April-2014-Balancing-the-risks-and-rewards-of-digital-technology.pdf|publisher=Ernst & Young LLP|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref> As a preventative measure, online brand protection providers are now adding social media to their domain and website discovery options.
===Security=== The widespread growth of social media has also made it easier for unauthorized individuals to impersonate an employee. Consequently, social media has now become a recognized threat vector in that it can be used to [[Social engineering (security)|socially engineer]] an attack on a business.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hinkley|first1=Chris|title=Social Media Makes Way for Social Engineering|url=http://www.securityweek.com/social-media-makes-way-social-engineering|website=SecurityWeek|publisher=Wired Business Media|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Bradley|first1=Tony|title=Think twice before you accept that 'friend' request|url=http://www.csoonline.com/article/2137134/social-engineering/think-twice-before-you-accept-that--friend--request.html|website=CSO|publisher=CXO Media, Inc.|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref> To counter this, companies are able to use web presence monitoring tools to detect new points of presence on the web and thereby defend against socially engineered attacks.<ref name="17th Annual Global CEO Survey"/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Foster|first1=James|title=A CISO's Nightmare: Digital Social Engineering|url=http://www.securityweek.com/cisos-nightmare-digital-social-engineering|website=SecurityWeek|publisher=Wired Business Media|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref><ref name="auto"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Security for social networking|url=http://www.pwc.com/en_US/us/it-risk-security/assets/social-networking-final.pdf|website=PwC|publisher=PwC|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Andreesen|first1=Tom|last2=Slemp|first2=Cal|title=Managing Risk in a Social Media-Driven Society|url=http://www.protiviti.com/en-US/Documents/Insights/Managing-Risk-in-a-Social-Media-Driven-Society.pdf|website=Protiviti|publisher=Protiviti, Inc.|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref>
===Distributed inventory management=== A web presence monitoring system can be used by a business to associate a new web property with its corporate inventory. It is designed to address autonomous, distributed behaviors. This usually applies to larger businesses whose geographically diverse employees are more prone to creating new points of presence on the web. For example, a retail chain may allow each local store to create and manage their web presence to market to and communicate with their local customer base.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Roberson|first1=Chip|title=Social Media for the Retail Industry - Going Local and Liking It!|url=http://www.brandle.net/blog/2013/10/social-media-retail-industry-going-local-liking|website=Brandle|publisher=Brandle, Inc.|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref> Similarly, a global business may have teams in each country or region who create and manage a web presence to adapt to local languages or cultures.
==Monitoring== Web presence monitoring is the process of monitoring a known inventory of web presence to detect any changes that are made. Web presence monitoring is often included in a web presence management system and can serve multiple purposes for both larger corporations and certain individuals, such as celebrities.
It is important to note that presence monitoring differs from content listening. The former involves monitoring the properties (e.g. branding) of a web property in an established inventory, whereas the latter refers to analyzing content that already exists to hear how a person or business is seen often in near real time.<ref>{{cite web|title=2015 Survey of Bank Compliance Officers|url=http://www.aba.com/Press/Pages/073015BankComplianceOfficerSurvey.aspx|website=ABA|publisher=American Bankers Association|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref> Additionally, presence monitoring focuses on owned media and content listening on earned media.
===Corporate, brand, and regulatory compliance=== Many companies ensure that certain standards are met for a property on the web that represents their business. For companies in regulated industries, such as finance and healthcare, the company may be required by law to ensure that all publicized content, regardless of platform or technology, follow specific requirements.<ref>{{cite web|title=Social Media: Consumer Compliance Risk Management Guidance|url=https://www.fdic.gov/news/news/financial/2013/fil13056a.pdf|website=FDIC|publisher=FFIEC|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Social Media Compliance Isn’t Fun, But It’s Necessary|url=https://hbr.org/2012/08/social-media-compliance-isnt|website=Harvard Business Review|publisher=Harvard Business School Publishing|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Regulatory Notice 10-06|url=http://www.finra.org/file/regulatory-notice-10-06|website=FINRA|publisher=FINRA|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref>
The widespread growth of social media has seen a rise in the number of fraudulent corporate impersonations. It has become much easier for a new web presence to be created on these platforms, and so these are much more prevalent than they used to be.<ref name=":0" /> As a preventative measure, a web presence monitoring system alerts the company when a known property is changed, allowing for the property to be reviewed and amended so that it follows the proper standards. .<ref name=":0">{{cite web|last1=Church|first1=Janet|last2=Roberson|first2=Chip|title=Social Media Risks and Rewards|url=http://www.scotsmanguide.com/Residential/Articles/2014/06/Social-Media-Risks-and-Rewards/|website=Scotsman Guide|publisher=Scotsman Guide Media|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref> A web presence monitoring system helps alert the company when a known property is changed, so it can be reviewed and brought back, if necessary, into compliance with the appropriate standards.
==Audit== A '''web presence audit''' is performed by an enterprise to determine that all [[Point of presence|points of presence]] on the web meet the objectives as well as [[governance, risk management, and compliance]] (GRC) needs. To ensure neutrality, these audits are often conducted as part of an [[information technology audit]] by a [[professional services]] agency or an internal audit team. However, a less formal web presence audit is often performed by internal members as a routine to meet GRC objectives.
A web presence audit usually includes web presence discovery and a review of all web-based content in the business’ inventory of web presence. Even though web presence monitoring is not performed in a web presence audit, a review of the nature and scope of the company's web presence monitoring policies, procedures, and tools is considered.
===Social media audit=== Due to the emerging challenges introduced by the dynamic nature of social media, a business may choose to perform specific '''social media audits''' in greater frequency.<ref>{{cite web|last1 = Juergens|first1 = Michael|title = Social Media Risks Create an Expanded Role for Internal Audit|url = http://deloitte.wsj.com/riskandcompliance/2013/08/06/social-media-risks-create-an-expanded-role-for-internal-audit/|website = Wall Street Journal|accessdate = 10 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1 = Dowie|first1 = Jon|title = EMERGING TECHNOLOGY RISKS - Social Media - Internal Audit’s response|url = https://www.kpmg.com/BE/en/IssuesAndInsights/ArticlesPublications/Documents/Social%20Media_ITIA's%20response.pdf|website = KPMG|accessdate = 10 August 2015}}</ref> A social media audit is similar to a web presence audit, but may also include the purposes of maintaining an accurate inventory of all business social media points of presence. Alternatively, the business may choose to employ automated web presence discovery and compliance systems to keep the corporate social media inventory up-to-date and compliant with GRC needs.
==Web presence vs. web reputation management== [[Reputation management|Reputation management systems]] are often associated with web presence management. Web presence management is knowing ''where'' an individual or business is represented, whereas [[reputation management]] is knowing ''what'' people are saying about an individual or business. Web presence management handles owned media, while reputation management systems with earned media.
Both systems offer some similar degree of remediation. For web presence management systems, remediation would include finding counterfeit properties that infringe on a brand or trademark. For reputation management systems, remediation would include identifying and eliminating misleading reviews and/or encouraging the contribution of authentic comments.
Even though a web presence monitoring tool can help identify unowned web properties where people are talking about a person, product, or brand, it is only part of the solution. A reputation management system often includes a content listening system to monitor the stream of messages about a particular subject which may be coming from any point of presence on the web (e.g. a comment about a product by a customer on her personal Twitter account). For examples of some [[:Category:Reputation management companies|reputation management companies, click here]].
==See also== {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Digital footprint]] * [[Domain name system]] * [[Earned media|Earned vs. Owned vs. Paid media]] * [[Internet presence management]] * [[Online identity]] * [[Online identity management]] * [[Online presence management]] * [[Online reputation management]] * [[Social media measurement]] * [[Social networking service]] * [[Web page]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Workforce Investment Boards''' (or "WIBs") were regional entities created to implement the [[Workforce Investment Act of 1998]] in the [[United States]], the [[Federated States of Micronesia]], the [[Republic of Palau]] and the [[Republic of the Marshall Islands]]. The implementing law was replaced by the [[Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act]] in 2014.
Every community in the fifty states, the [[District of Columbia]], [[Puerto Rico]], the [[United States Virgin Islands]], [[Guam]], [[American Samoa]], [[Northern Mariana Islands]], [[Federated States of Micronesia]], [[Republic of the Marshall Islands]], and [[Republic of Palau]], was associated with a Local WIB (LWIB). For each LWIB, a chief elected official (for example, a county commissioner or the mayor of a lead city) appointed members to sit on the WIB. These appointed positions were unpaid. At least 50% of a WIB's membership was required to come from private businesses. There were also designated seats for representatives from [[labor unions]] and educational institutions like [[community college]]s as well. Beyond these basic guidelines, many aspects of how an individual WIB operated could vary.
The WIB's main role was to direct [[Federal government of the United States|federal]], [[U.S. state|state]] and [[Local government|local]] funding to [[workforce development]] programs. WIBs conducted and published research on these programs and the needs of their regional economy. They also oversaw the [[One-Stop Career Centers]], where job seekers could get employment information, find out about career development training opportunities and connect to various programs in their area. One-Stop Career Centers also provided many no-cost services to employers. Services varied by state and WIB.
WIBs worked in conjunction with economic development related organizations to minimize the reaction time and create resources to intervene for both the dislocated workforce and the incumbent workforce members of a community.
==External links== * [http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getdoc.cgi?dbname=105_cong_public_laws&docid=f:publ220.105 Workforce Investment Act of 1998, from gpo.gov] * [http://www.nawb.org National Association of Workforce Boards] * [http://calworkforce.org California Workforce Association] * [http://www.fingerlakesworks.com www.fingerlakesworks.com] * [http://www.nyatep.org www.nyatep.org] * [http://www.nereta.org www.nereta.org]
[[Category:Workforce]] [[Category:Government of the United States]] [[Category:Economic development organizations in the United States]]

revision.text:
'''Zhang Dayi''' (张大奕) (born 1988) is a fashion entrepreneur/ designer who is a very successful [[internet celebrity]] (known as "[[Wanghong economy|wanghong]]" in China) on [[Sina Weibo]] and other sites in China. Her business is called ''[[Wuhuanxide Yichu]]'' (in English ''The Wardrobe I Like'')
==Description== Zhang Dayi was born in 1988 and she was a fashion student in China who has risen to be an [[internet celebrity]]. She was a fashion model in 2009<ref name=tech/> and in May 2014 she established her own on-line shop, Wuhuanxide Yichu, or "The Wardrobe I Like",<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://m.chinadaily.com.cn/en/2016-03/16/content_23887534.htm | title=Celebrity economy set for explosive growth in China | website=[[China Daily]] | author= Meng Jing (宋静丽)| date=16 March 2016 |access-date=2017-04-22}}</ref> in partnership with [[Feng Win]]. Feng Win had experience of establishing internet companies. The two chose [[Taobao]] as their prime site.<ref name=tech/>
In Dec 2017, she established her second online shop, KouHongMaiDiaoLeNe, or "The lipsticks have been sold out!", which sells cosmetics products made by her company. The lipsticks sold out in only two hours of landing, with the sales volume of 20,000.
She chats on her site and she has seven million followers on the Chinese equivalent of Twitter which is called [[Sina Weibo]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name="top10" /> In one video she will wear ten or so outfits and then chat live during the one hour webcast. A single video may be viewed nine million times showing outfits that are designed for her to wear.<ref name="tech">[http://technode.com/2017/03/20/fashion-influencers-in-china-a-new-force-for-retail-wanghong/ Fashion influencers in China: A new force for retail], 20 March 2017, Technode.com, Retrieved 20 April 2017</ref> It is estimated that she has thousands of pictures taken of her and then a few are chosen each day to reflect her image. Her factory soon employed 100 people.<ref name=":0" />
The largest shopping channel in China reported 5000 sales within seconds of a post featuring her in new clothing. She was reported to be in the top ten internet celebrities in 2016.<ref name=top10>[http://www.china.org.cn/top10/2016-03/25/content_38074050_2.htm Top 10 web celebrities in China], Lu Na,2016, China.org.cn, Retrieved 20 April 2017</ref>
Her annual income is reported as 300m yuan (£35m; $46m) in 2016. This was higher than the top Chinese actresses reported income.<ref name=bbc>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-36802769 Wang Hong: China's online stars making real cash], Grace Tsoi, 1 August 2016, BBC, Retrieved 20 April 2017</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1988 births]] [[Category:Internet celebrities]] [[Category:Chinese businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]]
